Recent wrestling news
*On November 9, [[THQ]] and [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE) released the fifth installment in the [[WWE SmackDown (video game series)|WWE SmackDown vs. Raw]] series, ''[[WWE SmackDown vs. Raw 2009]]''. *On November 10, WWE released [[Elijah Burke]], [[Kenny Dykstra]], and [[Lena Yada]] from their contracts. *[[Darren Matthews|William Regal]] defeated [[Santino Marella]] to win the [[WWE Intercontinental Championship]] on the November 10 episode of ''Raw''. *On November 18, WWE released [[Armando Estrada]] from his contract.
This fortnight in wrestling history
*[[November 10]], [[1991]] - [[William Afflis|Dick the Bruiser]] died at the age of 62 from [[internal bleeding]] *[[November 14]], [[1999]] - [[Paul Wight|The Big Show]] defeated [[Triple H]] to win the [[WWE Championship|WWF Championship]]. *[[November 15]], [[1998]] - [[Dwayne Johnson|The Rock]] defeated [[Mick Foley|Mankind]] in a tournament final for the [[WWE Championship|WWF Championship]]. *[[November 16]], [[1992]] - [[Jim Fullington|The Sandman]] defeated [[Don Muraco]] for the [[ECW Championship|ECW Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[November 17]], [[2002]] - [[Shawn Michaels]] defeated [[Triple H]], [[Glen Jacobs|Kane]], [[Chris Jericho]], [[Booker Huffman|Booker T]], and [[Rob Van Dam]] to win the [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)|World Heavyweight Championship]] in the first [[Elimination Chamber]]. *[[November 18]], [[2000]] - [[Nelson Erazo|Homicide]] defeated Jay Lover for the vacant [[JAPW Heavyweight Championship|Jersey All Pro Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[November 18]], [[2001]] - [[Adam Copeland|Edge]] [[championship unification|unified]] the [[WWE Intercontinental Championship|WWF Intercontinental]] and [[WWE United States Championship|United States]] championships. *[[November 18]], [[2001]] - [[The Dudley Boyz]] unified the [[World Tag Team Championship (WWE)|WWF]] and [[WCW Tag Team Championship|WCW Tag Team]] championships. *[[November 20]], [[2002]] - [[Jeff Jarrett]] defeated [[Ron Killings]] for the [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[November 21]], [[1999]] - [[Bret Hart]] defeated [[Chris Benoit]] in a tournament final for the [[WCW World Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[November 22]], [[1954]] - Promoter [[Roderick McMahon|Roderick "Jess" McMahon]] died at age 72.

Editing tips
This is a new section in the newsletter to help familiarize project members with the [[WP:MOS|Manual of Style]], which should help them in editing not only professional wrestling articles, but all articles in general. #Avoid using bolding to emphasize text. See [[MOS:BOLD]] for appropriate uses of bold text. #If you do not want your information removed from articles, please use proper grammar and [[WP:CITE|cite your sources]]. #Please avoid adding rumors to articles. Most rumors cannot be sourced with a [[WP:RS|reliable source]] and go against the [[WP:BLP|Biographies of Living Persons policy]]. #Avoid jargon such as [[Face (professional wrestling)|face/babayface]], [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heel]], [[List of professional wrestling terms#T|turn]], etc. in articles. People unfamiliar with professional wrestling will not understand what these words mean. See [[WP:JARGON]] for more information.

Recent wrestling news
*At [[Survivor Series (2008)|Survivor Series]]: **[[Adam Copeland|Edge]] returned and won the [[WWE Championship]] after [[Professional wrestling authority figures#General managers 2|SmackDown General Manager]] [[Vickie Guerrero]] added him to the match between then-champion [[Triple H]] and [[Oleg Prudius|Vladimir Kozlov]]. **[[John Cena]] returned after neck surgery, and won the [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)|World Heavyweight Championship]], for the first time, by defeating [[Chris Jericho]]. *On the November 24 episode of ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'', [[Dustin Runnels|Goldust]], [[Melina Perez|Melina]] and [[Mr. Kennedy]] made their television returns to [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE). *[[Steve Bradley]] died on December 4, 2008. His cause of death has not been determined. *On the December 5 episode of ''[[WWE Friday Night SmackDown|SmackDown]]'', [[Gregory Helms|Hurricane Helms]] made his in-ring return after an absence of over a year due to a neck injury.
This fortnight in wrestling history
*[[November 26]], [[1987]] - [[Ric Flair]] defeated [[Ron Garvin]] to win the [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[November 26]], [[1995]] - [[Smoky Mountain Wrestling]] ceased operation. *[[November 26]], [[2000]] - [[Scott Steiner]] defeated [[Booker Huffman|Booker T]] to win the [[WCW World Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[November 27]], [[1991]] - [[The Undertaker]] defeated [[Hulk Hogan]] for the [[WWE Championship|WWF Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[November 29]], [[2003]] - [[Larry Latham (wrestler)|Larry Lathman]], better known as Moondog Spot, died of a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] in the ring. *[[November 30]], [[1997]] - [[Shane Douglas]] defeated [[Bam Bam Bigelow]] to win the [[ECW Championship]]. *[[December 1]], [[1973]] - [[Stan Stasiak|Stan "The Man" Stasiak]] defeated [[Pedro Morales]] to win the [[WWE Championship|WWWF Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[December 5]], [[2003]] - [[Jerry Tuite]] died of a a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] aged 36. *[[December 7]], [[1996]] - [[Scott Levy|Raven]] defeated [[Jim Fullington|The Sandman]] to win the [[ECW Championship|ECW Heavyweight Championship]].

== Please stop messing with movie series == xXx has a third movie currently very much in the making, it is now a trilogy [http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1293847/], Ghotbusters 3 is very much in the making [http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1289401/], Batman 3 has not started production yet but is confirmed, French Connection is actually a tetralogy if you want to move it you can but don't just delete something, Transformers 3 hasn't been announced yet I'll grant you that and the Daniel Craig bond movies are very much considered a seperate series by many. As for Witch Mountain, it's at this point unclear if the new one is a remake or a sequel, if you delete it at least move it to the tetralogy section. I will once again revert your edit, please don't make it again. —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Happy Evil Dude|Happy Evil Dude]] ([[User talk:Happy Evil Dude|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Happy Evil Dude|contribs]]) 11:22, 10 December 2008 (UTC) === Re Trilogies === You're telling me that IMDB is not reliable and yet you send me an IMDB link.... Do you honestly believe that because Craig said he doesn't plan to do his third Bond movie right away that there won't be one? Let me remind you the man is signed for four more flicks. xXx 3 is confirmed, a script is being written, director and star are signed and there is a release date and start of filming date, what more do you need? Same for Ghostbusters 3, script is written, actors are confirmed, being signed. Transformers 3 isn't officially official, but the producers, director and screenwriters keep talking about it as though it was, a third movie is planned. Batman 3 WILL happen, it is confirmed, do you honestly think Warner Bros will not continue the franchise after the success it has had? Riddick already is a trilogy (Pitch Black & Dark Fury & CoR), parts 4 & 5 are being written. As for Spider-Man it may just be tv episodes strung together as movies, but other such things are listed so it has a place. Finally of course series with no wikilinks should be listed, so that people can create the damn articles. [[User:Happy Evil Dude|Happy Evil Dude]] ([[User talk:Happy Evil Dude|talk]]) 12:13, 10 December 2008 (UTC) :It's not a question of wish, it's fact. I think it's pretty safe to say that when a movie is in production with a script, director, actors, studio briefings, release date, etc, etc, it's pretty safe to assume it's going to be released. Sure anything can happen, but at this point Bond 23 is official, Iron Man 3 is official, Batman 3 is official, etc... just because the films haven't been released does not mean they do not have their place, Wikipedia does list "future films", there is a special template for that even. And if you make changes to a list such as this, please at least move the films to the "appropriate" section instead of simply deleting. Jeez. —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Happy Evil Dude|Happy Evil Dude]] ([[User talk:Happy Evil Dude|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Happy Evil Dude|contribs]]) 12:35, 10 December 2008 (UTC) ::Wikipedia ''does'' list future films, but [[WP:NFF]] also says that films are not created until they begin production. [[User:Darrenhusted|Darrenhusted]] ([[User talk:Darrenhusted#top|talk]]) 12:38, 10 December 2008 (UTC) :::All right just who do you think you are? You remind of why I'd become disgusted with editing Wikipedia a little less then a year ago when I kept adding Indiana Jones under tetralogy and people like you kept deleting it... Who are you to decide above the original filmmakers and film companies just how many movies are comprised in a franchise? You talk of films "not created" until they "begin production", then how do you account for you deleting my adds of Scooby-Doo, Batman 2005 and Riddick in the "trilogies" section? How do you account for deleting Fast & Furious from the tetralogy section? (I've since added it again, don't you dare delete it). How dare you say such films as Big Momma's House 3, Ghostbusters 3, xXx 3 are "wishful thinking" and that there is no official status to them when scripts are written, auditions are underway and filming is gearing up? Vanilla Sky 2 is wishful thinking, Iron Man 2 is not. Please try to understand that it's not up to you to decide what movies exist, it's up to the people who make them. [[User:Happy Evil Dude|Happy Evil Dude]] ([[User talk:Happy Evil Dude|talk]]) 23:01, 12 December 2008 (UTC) == Re: Rhodes == I've always been opposed to murder though... I think page protection is a good idea though. Off to request it now. ♥[[User:NiciVampireHeart|'''Nici''']]♥[[User_talk:NiciVampireHeart|'''Vampire''']]♥[[Special:Contributions/NiciVampireHeart|'''Heart''']]♥ 11:26, 19 December 2008 (UTC) :It's no problem! Thanks, and Merry Christmas! ♥[[User:NiciVampireHeart|'''Nici''']]♥[[User_talk:NiciVampireHeart|'''Vampire''']]♥[[Special:Contributions/NiciVampireHeart|'''Heart''']]♥ 11:45, 19 December 2008 (UTC) == RE: Cody Rhodes == {{User:L'Aquatique/tb}} == WikiProject Professional wrestling newsletter == {| class="navbox collapsible collapsed" style="text-align: left; border: 2px; margin-top: 0.2em;" |- ! colspan="2" valign="middle" style="width: 60%; border: 3px #039 solid; background-color: #FFFFFF; padding: 1em;" | [[Image:Barnstar-pro-wrestling.png|30px|left]]

Avoid creating new articles that do not satisfy the requirements. #If a sentence seems like it may not be true or is partially controversial, remove it or add {{fact}} directly after it.

Recent wrestling news
*At [[Final Resolution (December 2008)|Final Resolution]] **[[Eric Young (wrestler)|Eric Young]] defeated [[Shawn Daivari|Sheik Abdul Bashir]] to win the [[TNA X Division Championship]]. The [[Professional wrestling authority figures#Management Director|Management Director]] of [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]] (TNA), [[Jim Cornette]], stripped Young of the title after the event concluded due to interference from referee [[Shane Sewell]]. Cornette immediately set up a tournament afterwards for the X Division Championship to begin on the December 11 episode of ''[[TNA Impact!]]''. **Suicide, played by [[Frankie Kazarian]], a character from [[TNA Impact! (video game)|TNA Impact the video game]], debuted after weeks of promotion. *On the December 8 episode of ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'', [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE) held the [[Slammy Award]]s for the first time in eleven years. *[[Gene Snitsky]] was released from his WWE contract on December 11. *[[John Morrison and The Miz]] defeated [[CM Punk]] and [[Kofi Kingston]] at a WWE [[house show|live event]] on December 13 to win the [[World Tag Team Championship (WWE)|World Tag Team Championship]]. *At [[Armageddon (2008)|Armageddon]], [[Jeff Hardy]] defeated [[Adam Copeland|Edge]] and [[Triple H]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches|Triple threat match]] to win the [[WWE Championship]], his first [[World Heavyweight Championship (professional wrestling)|World Heavyweight Championship]] reign in WWE.
This fortnight in wrestling history
*[[December 9]], [[1974]] - [[Jack Brisco]] defeated [[Shohei Baba]] for the [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[December 9]], [[2001]] - [[Chris Jericho]] became the first [[WWE Championship|WWF Undisputed Champion]] after beating [[Stone Cold Steve Austin|Steve Austin]] to win the [[WWE Championship|WWF Championship]] and defeating [[Dwayne Johnson|The Rock]] to win the [[WCW World Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[December 10]], [[1973]] - [[Bruno Sammartino]] defeated [[Stan Stasiak]] for the [[WWE Championship|WWWF Heavyweight Chamspionship]]. *[[December 13]], [[2003]] - [[Dan Lopez|Danny Maff]] defeated [[Jerry Lawler]] to win the [[JAPW Heavyweight Championship|Jersey All Pro Wrestling Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[December 14]], [[1963]] - [[Verne Gagne]] defeated [[Reginald Lisowski|The Crusher]] for the [[AWA World Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[December 14]], [[2001]] - [[Russ Haas]] died of a [[heart attack]] at age 27. *[[December 15]], [[2002]] - [[Kurt Angle]] defeated [[Paul Wight|The Big Show]] for the [[WWE Championship]]. *[[December 17]], [[1999]] - [[Masato Tanaka]] defeated [[Mike Awesome]] to win the [[ECW Championship|ECW World Heavyweight Championship]]. *[[December 20]], [[1999]] - [[Bret Hart]] won the [[WCW World Heavyweight Championship]] by defeating [[Bill Goldberg|Goldberg]].

Editing tips
This is a new section in the newsletter to help familiarize project members with the [[WP:MOS|Manual of Style]] and general editing tips. #When expanding [[WP:PW/PPV|pay-per-view articles]], avoid using [[Professional wrestling terms|wrestling jargon]] without an explanation, per [[WP:JARGON]], maintain an out-of-universe perspective of the article, per [[WP:IN-U]], and avoid writing in excess detail, per [[WP:PLOT]]. For further information see [[WP:PW/PPVG]]. #Our project has a cleanup listing. Please help by adding sources or expanding any articles listed [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Professional wrestling/Cleanup listing|here]]. #Per [[WP:MOSCAPS]], television shows, such as ''[[WWE Raw|RAW]]'' and [[TNA Impact!|iMPACT!]], should be written as ''Raw'' and ''Impact!''. #Due to a new consensus formed by Wikipedia users, dates should be unlinked in all articles, per [[WP:MOSNUM]]. #Please familiarize yourself with the [[WP:N|general notability policy]] of Wikipedia. Avoid creating new articles that do not satisfy the requirements. #Avoid [[WP:OVERLINK|overlinking]] in an article. If a subject has been linked once already in the body paragraphs, there is no need to link it again, unless the length of the article requires it to be linked a second time. Lists are the only exceptions to this policy.

Recent deletion debates
*'''[[WP:AFD|Articles for Deletion]]''' **'''Deleted:''' [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Chris Bang|Chris Bang]], [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Blackjack Parsons|Blackjack Parsons]], and [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Vince Verhei (2nd nomination)|Vince Verhei]]. **'''Kept:''' [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/TNA Weekly PPV|TNA Weekly PPV]] *'''[[WP:IFD|Images for Deletion]] **'''Deleted:''' [[Wikipedia:Possibly unfree images/2008 December 28#File:Jillian Hall about to use Samoan Drop on Candice Michelle.jpg|File:Jillian Hall about to use Samoan Drop on Candice Michelle.jpg]] and [[Wikipedia:Possibly unfree images/2008 December 28#File:Jillian Hall doing cartwheel into an elbow drop.jpg|File:Jillian Hall doing cartwheel into an elbow drop.jpg]]. *'''[[WP:MFD|Miscellany for Deletion]] **'''Current:''' [[Wikipedia:Miscellany for deletion/Wikipedia:WikiProject Professional wrestling/Calendar|Wikiproject Professional wrestling/Calender]]
Recent wrestling news
*On December 22: **On ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'', [[Trish Stratus]] wrestled her first match in over two years in her native [[Toronto, Ontario|Toronto, Canada]]. She and [[John Cena]] defeated [[Santino Marella]] and [[Beth Phoenix]] in a [[Tag team#Tag team match rules|Tag team match]]. **It was reported by [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] that [[Dave Batista|Batista]] was sidelined with a [[hamstring]] tear that required surgery. **[[Maryse Ouellet|Maryse]] defeated [[Michelle McCool]] to win the [[WWE Divas Championship]] on an episode of ''[[WWE Friday Night SmackDown|Friday Night SmackDown]]'', which aired on December 26. *On December 26: **Independent Wrestling Association's Roland Montgomery, known as Rollin' Hard, died at his home in [[Louisville, Kentucky]]. **WWE Divas Champion Maryse dislocated her kneecap at a WWE [[house show|live event]]; it is unknown how long the injury will sideline her from in-ring competition. *[[World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE) moved [[Paul Burchill]] and [[Katie Lea]] from the Raw brand to the [[Extreme Championship Wrestling (WWE)|ECW]] brand on December 30. *On January 2, [[United States senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Henry Waxman]] filed a letter to the [[Office of National Drug Control Policy]] requesting a review of [[professional wrestling]]'s [[steroid]] testing and usage.
This fortnight in wrestling history
*December 22, 2000 - [[Mike Rapada]] defeated [[Terry Brunk|Sabu]] to win the [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]]. *December 23, 1999 - [[Mike Awesome]] defeated [[Masato Tanaka]] to win the [[ECW Championship|ECW World Heavyweight Championship]]. *December 26, 1983 - The [[Iron Sheik]] defeated [[Bob Backlund]] for the [[WWE Championship|WWF Heavyweight Championship]]. *December 28, 1997 - [[Steve Borden|Sting]] defeated [[Hulk Hogan]] to win the [[WCW World Heavyweight Championship|WCW Heavyweight Championship]] *December 29, 1998 - [[Mick Foley|Mankind]] defeated [[Dwayne Johnson|The Rock]] to win the [[WWE Championship|WWF World Heavyweight Championship]]. *January 3, 2000 - [[Triple H]] defeated [[Paul Wight|The Big Show]] for the [[WWE Championship|WWF Heavyweight Championship]]. *January 4, 1999 - [[Keiji Mutoh]] defeated [[Scott Norton]] for the [[IWGP Heavyweight Championship]].

==WP:FILMS Questionnaire== As a member of [[Wikipedia:Wikiproject Films|WikiProject Films]], you are invited to take part in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Films/Questionnaire 1|project's first questionnaire]]. It is intended to gauge your participation and views on the project. At the conclusion of the questionnaire, the project's [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Films/Coordinators|coordinators]] will use the gathered feedback to find new ways to improve the project and reach out to potential members. The results of the questionnaire will be published in next month's newsletter. If you know of any editors who have edited film articles in the past, please invite them to take part in the questionnaire. Please stop by and take a few minutes to answer the questions so that we can continue to improve our project. Happy editing!

[[File:Mt Vesuvius 79 AD eruption 3.svg|350px|right|thumb|Stabiae and other cities affected by the eruption of [[Mount Vesuvius]]. The black cloud represents the general distribution of ash and cinder. Modern coast lines are shown.]]'''Stabiae''' was an ancient [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] town, located close to the modern town of [[Castellammare di Stabia]] approximately 4.5 km southwest of [[Pompeii]]. It was positioned on a 50 m high headland overlooking the [[Gulf of Naples]].<ref>
[http://www.sdmart.org/exhibition-stabiano.html San Diego Museum of Art exhibition on Stabiae]
</ref><ref name="restoring">[http://stabiae.org/usa/index2.html Restoring Stabiae website]
</ref> Being only {{convert|16|km|mi}} from [[Mount Vesuvius]], this [[seaside resort]] was largely destroyed by two metres of [[tephra]] ash in 79 AD.

Originally a small [[port]], by the 6th century BC Stabiae had already been overshadowed by the much larger port at [[Pompeii]]. The town was destroyed by [[Lucius Cornelius Sulla]] on 30 April 89 BC during the [[Social War (91–88 BC)|Social War]], a [[revolt]] by many of Rome's allies in the area. The Roman [[author]] and [[admiral]] [[Pliny the Elder]] recorded that the town was rebuilt and became a popular resort for wealthy Romans. He reported that there were several miles of luxury villas built along the edge of the headland, all enjoying panoramic views out over the bay.<ref name="restoring"/>

According to the account<ref>
[http://www.classics.cam.ac.uk/Pompeii/Destruction.html Account of Pliny's death] (the famous letter by Pliny's nephew, Pliny the Younger, in Latin and English)
</ref> written by [[Pliny the Younger|his nephew]], Pliny the Elder was at the other side of the bay in [[Misenum]] when the eruption started. He travelled by [[galley]] ship across the bay, partly to observe the eruption more closely, and partly to rescue people from the coast near the volcano.

Pliny died at Stabiae the following day, probably during the arrival of the sixth and largest [[pyroclastic surge]] of the eruption caused by the collapse of the [[eruption plume]].<ref>
{{cite book  | title=Volcanoes| publisher=Oxford University Press| year=2004  | author=Francis, Peter & Oppenheimer, Clive| isbn=0-19-925469-9}}
</ref> The very diluted outer edge of this surge reached Stabiae and left two centimetres of fine ash on top of the immensely thick aerially-deposited tephra which further protected the underlying remains.

== Archaeological ruins ==
[[File:Primavera di Stabiae.jpg|300px|left|thumb|Primavera di Stabiae]]

===History===
[[File:S03 06 01 001 image 382.jpg|thumbnail|1895. View from Baths of Stabiae. Brooklyn Museum Archives, Goodyear Archival Collection]]
The archaeological remains of Stabiae were originally discovered in 1749 by Cavaliere Rocco de Alcubierre, an engineer working for king  [[Charles III of Spain|Charles VII of Naples]].<ref name="Parslow">
{{cite book | title=Rediscovering Antiquity: Karl Weber and the Excavation of Herculaneum, Pompeii, and Stabiae | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=1995 | author= Parslow, Christopher Charles | isbn= 0-521-47150-8}}
</ref>  These ruins were partially excavated by Alcubierre with help from [[Karl Weber (archaeologist)|Karl Weber]] between 1749–1782.<ref name="Parslow"/> The ruins that had been excavated, however, were reburied and their location was forgotten until 1950, when a high school principal rediscovered them.<ref name="restoring"/>  The site was declared an archaeological protected area in 1957, and by 1962 many of the ruins had been again uncovered. The remains of both an [[Oscan]] settlement (oppidum) and the later Roman town were discovered.<ref name="Encyclopedia">[http://search.eb.com.turing.library.northwestern.edu/eb/article-9069333 Encyclopædia Britannica Website]
</ref>

The most famous of the findings at Stabiae are the villas that come from the time between the destruction of Stabiae by Sulla in 89 BC and the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD.<ref name="Senatore">
{{cite book | title=Stabiae: Dalla preistoria alla guerra greco-gotica | publisher=Edizioni Spano | year=2003 | author= Felice Senatore | isbn=88-88226-15-X}}
</ref>  As described above, Stabiae became a resort town during this time and was particularly favored for its view of the Bay of Naples and the surrounding mountains.<ref name="restoring"/> Stabiae was also well known for the quality of its spring water, which was believed to have medicinal properties.<ref name="Encyclopedia"/>  The ideal placement and qualities of this location drew  many wealthy Romans to build luxurious villas on the ridge overlooking the bay.  These villas, which are described below, provide us with some of the most stunning architectural and artistic remains from Roman villas. 2004 saw an Italian-American collaboration between the Superintendency of Archaeology of Pompeii, the region of Campania and the University of Maryland to form the non-profit Archaeological entity, the Restoring Ancient Stabiae Foundation (RAS). It is the RAS Foundation's prime goal to excavate, restore and build an archaeological park at the ancient site of Stabiae, a complex of seven or eight Roman villas according to recent geophysical surveys conducted by the University of Birmingham.

A great many [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] which come from Stabiae are preserved in the [[Naples National Archaeological Museum]].

===Pre-Roman settlement===

Before the age of the villas, however, an [[Oscan]] settlement existed in the region of Stabiae.  In 1957 three hundred tombs dating from the 7th to the 3rd centuries BC were found in a [[necropolis]] associated with this town.  Many pieces of pottery were found in these tombs and provide us with archaeological evidence that supports the dating of the Oscan inhabitants.<ref name="Senatore" />  It appears that the [[Samnites]] later took over the Oscan town in the 5th century.<ref>
[http://search.eb.com.turing.library.northwestern.edu/eb/article-5859 Encyclopædia Britannica Website]
</ref>

===Villas===
[[File:Villa San Marco - Atrio.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Villa San Marco]]
Among the many villas found at Stabiae, the most famous are Villa San Marco, Villa Del Pastore, and Villa Arianna. Some of the other villas include Villa Carmiano, Villa del Petraro, and Villa Capella di San Marco.

====Villa San Marco====
This villa, deriving the name from a chapel that existed in its proximity in the 18th century, was the first one to be explored in the course of excavations in [[Charles III of Spain|Bourbon]] times carried out between 1749 and 1754.  The graphic and textual documentation of the Bourbon surveys was published in 1881 by M. Ruggiero M. in the book ''Degli Scavi di Stabiae dal 1749 al 1782'' ("On the Stabiae excavations from 1749 to 1782"). The villa was re-buried after the removal of its furnishings and of the better preserved frescoes. Excavations were resumed on 1950 by Libero d’Orsi and O. Elia of the Archaeological Superintendency.

One of the largest villas ever discovered in [[Campania]], measuring more than 11,000 square metres,<ref name="restoring" /> it has an [[Atrium (architecture)|atrium]], a courtyard containing a98> pool, a [[triclinium]] with views of the bay, and a colonnaded courtyard.  There are also many other small rooms, a kitchen and two internal gardens.  Villa San Marco also has a private bath complex that is made up of a [[calidarium]], [[tepidarium]], and a [[frigidarium]].  This villa is also important because it has provided  frescoes, sculptures, mosaics and architecture, which show styles and themes comparable to those found in Pompeii and Herculaneum.

====Villa del Pastore====
[[File:Villa del Pastore Pastore.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Shepherd from the Villa del Pastore]]
"Villa of the Shepherd" in English.  This villa gets its name from a small statue of a shepherd that was discovered at this site.  This villa measures even larger than Villa San Marco, coming in at 19,000 square metres.  The villa was rediscovered in 1967 and includes many rooms, large baths and luxurious gardens.  It lacks, however, any domestic rooms, suggesting that it may not have been a residence. One hypothesis is that this is instead a [[valetudinarium]] (health spa) that would have allowed people to take advantage of the famous spring waters of Stabiae. It has not yet been fully excavated.

====Villa Arianna====
[[File:Stanza del mito di Arianna.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Villa Arianna]]
Named for the fresco depicting [[Dionysus]] saving [[Ariadne]] from the island of Dia (a mythological name for Naxos), this villa is particularly famous for its frescoes, many of which depict light, winged figures.<ref name= "restoring" />  It is difficult to get a clear sense of this villa, however, because it grew over the course of 150 years.  It has one of the largest courtyards of any Roman villa; measuring two stadia in length.  Another feature of Villa Arianna is its private tunnel system that links the villa in its location on the ridge to the sea shore, which was probably only between 100 and 200 metres away from the bottom of the hill in Roman times.  The shoreline has since changed, leaving the archaeological site further inland than it was in antiquity.

title: Wikipedia:No firm rules
content:
{{warning|This is a '''workshop''' page, and not the actual policy page of Wikipedia's Ignore All Rules. If you are looking for the official policy, please click '''[[WP:IAR|here instead]]'''}} {| class="messagebox plainlinks" |- | [[Image:Green check.png|30px]] | '''The following is [[Wikipedia:Policies and guidelines|policy]] on the English Wikipedia''', and according to [[User:Jimbo Wales|Jimbo Wales]], it "[{{fullurl:Wikipedia:Ignore all rules|diff=70516723}} always has been]." ''Ignore all rules'' was Wikipedia's first [{{fullurl:RulesToConsider|oldid=277053}} rule to consider]. | {{shortcut|WP:IAR|WP:IGNORE}} |} {{cquote|If a [[Wikipedia:Policies and guidelines|rule]] prevents you from improving or maintaining [[Wikipedia]], '''ignore it'''.}} ==What "Ignore all rules" means== You do not need to read any rules before contributing to Wikipedia. If you do what seems sensible, it will usually be right, and if it's not right, don't worry. Even the worst mistakes are easy to correct: older versions of a page remain in the [[Help:page_history|revision history]] and can be restored. If we disagree with your changes, we'll talk about it thoughtfully and politely, and we'll figure out what to do. So don't worry. [[Wikipedia:Be Bold|Be bold]], and enjoy helping to build this free encyclopedia. *You are not required to learn the rules before contributing. Yes, we already said that, but it is worth repeating. *Don't follow written instructions mindlessly, but rather, consider how the encyclopedia is improved or damaged by each edit. (See also [[Wikipedia:Use common sense]].) *Rules derive their power to compel not from being written down on a page labelled "guideline" or "policy", but from being a reflection of the shared opinions and practices of a great many editors. (See also [[Wikipedia:Consensus]].) *Most rules are ultimately ''descriptive'', not ''prescriptive''; they describe existing current practice. They sometimes lag behind the practices they describe. (See also [[Wikipedia:Product, process, policy]].) *[[Wikipedia:WikiLawyering|WikiLawyering]] doesn't work. Loopholes and technicalities do not exist on the Wiki. Wikipedia is [[WP:BURO|not a bureaucracy]]; not [[moot court]], nor [[nomic]], nor [[Mao (game)|Mao]]. *The spirit of the rule trumps the letter of the rule. The common purpose of building a free encyclopedia trumps both. If this common purpose is better served by ignoring the letter of a particular rule, then that rule should perhaps be ignored. *Following the rules is less important than using good judgment and being thoughtful and considerate, always bearing in mind that good judgment is not displayed only by those who agree with you. (See also [[Wikipedia:Civility]].) ==What "Ignore all rules" does not mean== Despite its name, "[[Wikipedia:Ignore all rules|Ignore all rules]]" does not sabotage the other rules. Its purpose is to keep them from sabotaging what we're doing here: building a free encyclopedia. Rules have ''zero'' importance compared with that goal. If they aid that goal, good. If they interfere with it, they are instantly negated. *"Ignore all rules" does not mean that every action is justifiable. It is neither a [[Trump (card game)|trump card]] nor a [[wiktionary:carte blanche|carte blanche]]. A rule-ignorer must justify how their actions improve the encyclopedia if challenged. Actually, everyone should be able to do that at all times. In cases of conflict, what counts as an improvement is decided by consensus. *"Ignore all rules" does not stop you from pointing out a rule to someone who has broken it, but do consider that their judgment may have been correct. (See also [[Wikipedia:Assume good faith]].) *"Ignore all rules" is not an answer if someone asks you why you broke a rule. Most of the rules are derived from a lot of thoughtful experience and exist for pretty good reasons; they should therefore only be broken for good reasons. *"Ignore all rules" is not an exemption from accountability. You're still responsible for reasonably foreseeable effects of your actions on the encyclopedia and on other editors. *"Ignore all rules" is not an invitation to use Wikipedia for purposes contrary to that of building a free encyclopedia. (See also [[Wikipedia:About]] and [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not]].) *"Ignore all rules" does not mean there is necessarily an exception to every rule. Blatant [[WP:COPYVIO|copyright violations]], for instance, do not make for a better free encyclopedia (although [[WP:FAIRUSE|limited uses]] of copyrighted material are acceptable). == See also == {| class="infobox sisterproject noprint plainlinks" style="width: auto;" |- | [[File:Sound-icon 30px.png|30x23px|link=Wikipedia:Spoken articles]] |'''Listen to this policy''' ([[:Image:Ignore_all_rules.ogg|info / help]])
[[:Media:Ignore_all_rules.ogg|in media player]] {{·}} [http://tools.wikimedia.de/~gmaxwell/jorbis/JOrbisPlayer.php?path={{urlencode:Ignore_all_rules.ogg}}&wiki=en in browser]''' |} *[[Wikipedia:Understanding IAR|Wikipedia:Understanding ''Ignore all rules'']] * [[Wikipedia:Do not disrupt Wikipedia to illustrate a point]] {{-}} {{Wikipedia principles}}

image_size = | alias = | origin = [[Waldorf, Maryland]], United States | genre = [[Pop punk]],{{cite web |url=http://www.sweetslyrics.com/reviews-4586-Good%20Charlotte%20-%20Cardiology.html |author=MacKenzie Wilson |title=Good Charlotte |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/good-charlotte-p442724 |work=[[AllMusic]] |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] |accessdate=January 16, 2012 |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20110103001625/http://www.sweetslyrics.com/reviews-4586-Good%20Charlotte%20-%20Cardiology.html |archivedate=2011-01-03 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://www.sputnikmusic.com/review/39881/Good-Charlotte-Cardiology/ |title=Good Charlotte – Cardiology |publisher=Sputnik |date=October 26, 2010 |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20121020183308/http://sputnikmusic.com/review/39881/Good-Charlotte-Cardiology/ |archivedate=2012-10-20 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |author=Jason Ankeny |title=New Found Glory |url=http://allmusic.com/artist/new-found-glory-p384007/biography |work=[[AllMusic]] |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20120428071914/http://www.allmusic.com/artist/new-found-glory-p384007/biography |archivedate=2012-04-28 |deadurl=no}} [[alternative rock]]{{cite web |url=http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/reviews/events/30750/Good-Charlotte-plays-Weezer-Selinas-Sydney-111111 |title=Good Charlotte Plays Weezer @ Selina's Sunday |publisher=Faster Louder |date=November 11, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104025557/http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/reviews/events/30750/Good-Charlotte-plays-Weezer-Selinas-Sydney-111111 |archivedate=2014-01-04 |deadurl=no}} | years_active = 1995–2011, 2015–present | label = [[Daylight Records|Daylight]], [[Epic Records|Epic]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[Kobalt Label Services|Kobalt]] | associated_acts = [[Dead Executives]], [[Taintstick]], [[The Used]], [[Wakefield (band)|Wakefield]], [[The Summer Obsession]], [[Avenged Sevenfold]], [[Boys Like Girls]], [[Sum 41]], [[Lionel Richie]], [[Short Stack]], [[New Empire (band)|New Empire]], [[The Madden Brothers]], [[Tonight Alive]], [[5 Seconds of Summer]] | website = {{URL|http://www.goodcharlotte.com/}} | current_members = [[Joel Madden]]
[[Benji Madden]]
[[Paul Thomas (bassist)|Paul Thomas]]
[[Billy Martin (guitarist)|Billy Martin]]
[[Dean Butterworth]] | past_members = [[Aaron Escolopio]]
Chris Wilson }} '''Good Charlotte''' are an American [[rock music|rock]] band from [[Waldorf, Maryland]] that formed in 1996. Since 1998, the band's constant members have been lead vocalist [[Joel Madden]], rhythm guitarist and vocalist [[Benji Madden]], bassist [[Paul Thomas (bassist)|Paul Thomas]], lead guitarist and keyboardist [[Billy Martin (guitarist)|Billy Martin]] and drummer [[Dean Butterworth]], who has been a member of the band since 2005. After embarking on a 4-year-long hiatus in 2011, the band announced its comeback on 3 November, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://goodcharlotte.com/post/132474098862/httpwwwaltpresscomnewsentrygoodcharlottea|title=Good Charlotte|work=Good Charlotte}} The band has released five studio albums: ''[[Good Charlotte (album)|Good Charlotte]]'' (2000), ''[[The Young and the Hopeless]]'' (2002), ''[[The Chronicles of Life and Death]]'' (2004), ''[[Good Morning Revival]]'' (2007), and ''[[Cardiology (album)|Cardiology]]'' (2010) with sixth ''[[Youth Authority]]'' stated for release in July 2016, as well as two compilations: ''[[Greatest Remixes]]'' (2008) and ''[[Greatest Hits (Good Charlotte album)|Greatest Hits]]'' (2010). ==History== ===Early years (1996–1998)=== Each original member of the band attended [[La Plata High School]] in [[Maryland]]. The band made a name for itself in nearby [[Washington, D.C.]], playing the WHFS annual rock show [[HFStival]] in 1998 and 1999.{{cite web |author=MacKenzie Wilson |url=http://allmusic.com/artist/good-charlotte-p442724/biography |title=Good Charlotte |publisher=AllMusic |date=October 27, 2000 |accessdate=November 8, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427154704/http://www.allmusic.com/artist/good-charlotte-p442724/biography |archivedate=2012-04-27 |deadurl=no}} The band mainly played out small bars which soon earned the group attention. === ''Good Charlotte'' (1999–2001) === Good Charlotte's debut studio album ''[[Good Charlotte (album)|Good Charlotte]]'' was released in 2000 and was the start of the band's music career. The album contains three singles: "Little Things", "Motivation Proclamation", and "Festival Song". [[Aaron Escolopio]] was the band's drummer for this album, but left the band before ''[[The Young and the Hopeless]]'' to join his brother's band [[Wakefield (band)|Wakefield]], and was replaced by Nate Foutz (drummer of the band [[Vroom (band)|Vroom]]). === ''The Young and the Hopeless'' (2002–2003) === 2002's ''[[The Young and the Hopeless]]'' sold 4.9 million copies and thrust the band into mainstream popularity. The band's breakthrough single, titled "[[Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous (Good Charlotte song)|Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous]]", topped both pop and rock charts around the globe. Singles that were released from the album include "[[The Anthem (Good Charlotte song)|The Anthem]]", "[[Girls & Boys (Good Charlotte song)|Girls & Boys]]", "[[The Young & the Hopeless|The Young and the Hopeless]]", and "[[Hold On (Good Charlotte song)|Hold On]]". The band cited [[Rancid (band)|Rancid]], [[Social Distortion]], and [[The Clash]] as influences for the album. The album eventually went on to receive triple platinum certification (three million copies sold) from the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]].{{cite web |url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH |title=RIAA Certification Database |publisher=Riaa.com |accessdate=August 19, 2011 |archiveurl=}} During the course of the album's success, Good Charlotte landed appearances on ''[[American Idol]]'', CNN, and ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'', the covers of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and ''[[Alternative Press]]'' magazines, and were also featured in ''[[The New York Times]]''. The band also became popular on MTV, where the band's music videos were played in heavy rotation on both MTV and [[MTV2]]. "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous" received the "Viewers Choice Award" at the [[2003 MTV Video Music Awards#Viewer's Choice|2003 MTV Video Music Awards]]. After a few months of touring, Nate Foutz (Vroom Drummer) returned to join his band for the band's summer tour. The band hired drummers during the recording, release and touring of ''The Young and the Hopeless'' due to former drummer [[Aaron Escolopio]] having left the band before its release. In 2003, the band added Chris Wilson as a drummer; he was introduced to the band through mutual friends from the group [[The Used]]. === ''The Chronicles of Life and Death'' (2004–2007) === Good Charlotte's third album, ''[[The Chronicles of Life and Death]]'', was released by Epic Records in 2004. The album received mixed reactions from both the music press and Good Charlotte's fan base. The album sold 2.2 million copies. The album has been widely considered a departure from the band's previous two albums, mixing new elements such as lyrical topics into Good Charlotte's youthful sound. Singles released from the album include the two hits "[[Predictable (Good Charlotte song)|Predictable]]" and "[[I Just Wanna Live]]", as well as "[[The Chronicles of Life and Death (song)|The Chronicles of Life and Death]]" and "[[We Believe]]". The only single from ''The Chronicles of Life and Death'' which managed to chart on the U.S. Hot 100 was the hit "I Just Wanna Live". All of the singles released from the album went top 30 in the UK, except for "We Believe". The band would then go on tour with [[Sum 41]]. In May 2005, after much speculation from fans, it was officially confirmed that Chris Wilson had left the band citing personal health reasons. Benji also told ''[[Kerrang!]]'' magazine that, for him, "Chris leaving the band was the worst part of 2005." Chris then joined the pop/punk band [[The Summer Obsession]] until 2011. He currently plays drums for [[JMSN]]. On Good Charlotte's "Noise to the World" Tour, performing with [[Simple Plan]] and [[Relient K]], the band recruited [[Dean Butterworth]] (who had previously played for [[Morrissey]]) as the band's temporary drummer. Later, in March 2007, Butterworth was confirmed as the band's permanent drummer. [[Benji Madden]] has claimed in interviews that he feels this record was not as successful as the previous record due to it being "too selfish."{{cite web |title=Boys Like Girls, Good Charlotte deliver insincere sets |url=http://www.azcentral.com/thingstodo/music/articles/2008/07/22/20080722boyslikegirlsreview.html?nclick_check=1 |work=azcentral.com |accessdate=December 21, 2013 |author=Maria Verso |date=July 22, 2008 |quote=From the moment Good Charlotte took the stage with The Anthem – "It's a new day but it all feels old." You remember, right? – you realized that Good Charlotte is the Soundtrack of Your Summer if that summer happened to be 2002. Steering clear of The Chronicles of Life and Death, the 2004 album that Benji Madden later said was not successful because it was "too selfish," the band mostly stuck to The Young and Hopeless game plan with a smattering of new songs from last year's less glum Good Morning Revival. |subscription=yes |archiveurl=}} {{link note|note=30 day free access without a subscription}}{{better source|date=December 2013|reason=A primary-source interview would be best}} === ''Good Morning Revival'' (2007–2008) === [[File:Good Charlotte - 2007.jpg|thumb|Good Charlotte in 2007 on the group's float in the [[Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade]]]] ''[[Good Morning Revival]]'' is the fourth album by Good Charlotte and the follow-up to 2004's ''The Chronicles of Life and Death''. It was officially released in March 2007, with the precise date varying by country.''Good Morning Revival'' debuted in the top 10 of thirteen countries worldwide including the U.S., giving the band some of its highest international chart positions thus far, and went on to sell 4.5 million copies. At midnight, on January 23, 2007, the record was made available for pre-order on [[iTunes]]. When pre-ordered, the single "[[The River (Good Charlotte song)|The River]]" could be downloaded immediately, while the rest of the album was queued to be downloaded on the release date. Pre-ordering on iTunes also provided the exclusive bonus acoustic version of the song. This album was suggested a different sound for the group apart from the group's pop punk roots. The first single from the album, "[[The River (Good Charlotte song)|The River]]", featuring [[Avenged Sevenfold]]'s lead singer [[M. Shadows]] and guitarist [[Synyster Gates]], appeared online on January 4, 2007, and was released as the first single from the album in North America. The music video for "The River" was added to UK music channels [[Kerrang! TV|Kerrang!]] and [[Scuzz]] on April 13, 2007, making it the second single released from the album in the UK. The song charted at No. 108. "Keep Your Hands off My Girl" was released as the first single in the UK and Australia. "Keep Your Hands Off My Girl" charted on the [[UK Singles Chart]] at No. 36 the first week of release through download sales and then climbed to No. 23 when released in stores. The second single released in North America was "[[Dance Floor Anthem (I Don't Want to Be in Love)|Dance Floor Anthem]]", with which the band had scored a surprise hit, making it onto 11 different Billboard charts and peaking at No. 2 in Australia.{{Citation needed|date=January 2014}} The "Keep Your Hands Off My Girl" video was certified gold by [[MTV International]] in December 2007. It was played 3,000 times on over 4 continents during the first half of 2007.{{cite web |title=Keep Your Hands Off My Girl – Video Certified GOLD by MTV International |url=http://www.goodcharlotte.com/news/keep-your-hands-my-girl-video-certified-gold-mtv-international |website=Goodcharlotte.com |author=Good Charlotte band |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206033451/http://www.goodcharlotte.com/ |archivedate=2007-12-05 |date=December 5, 2007}}{{cite news |title=MTV launches global video play awards |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/media/news/a81068/mtv-launches-global-video-play-awards.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103125321/http://www.digitalspy.com/media/news/a81068/mtv-launches-global-video-play-awards.html |archivedate=2014-01-03 |deadurl=no |publisher=Digital Spy |accessdate=3 January 2014 |author=James Welsh |date=December 4, 2007 |quote=Gold (more than 3000 plays) ... Good Charlotte – 'Keep Your Hands Off My Girl'}} On January 1, 2008, Good Charlotte was featured on Tila Tequila's New Year's Eve Masquerade on MTV, as the band was the second performance of the new year and performed its hit "Dance Floor Anthem". The band made multiple U.S. and international TV appearances in support of the album. First, Good Charlotte appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' on April 9, 2007, the Outdoor Stage on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' on April 11, and on ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]'' on April 27. Joel and Benji Madden, Good Charlotte's lead singer and guitarist respectively, co-hosted the [[MTV Australia Video Music Awards|Australian MTV Video Music Awards]] with [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]] on April 29, 2007 where the band also won the "Viewers Choice Australia" award for "Keep Your Hands Off My Girl". In August 2007, the band embarked on [[Justin Timberlake]]'s [[FutureSex/LoveShow]] tour, as Timberlake's opening act. Good Charlotte supported Timberlake throughout his second leg North American dates. The band was present for the August 16, 2007 show in [[Madison Square Garden]], which was taped for a HBO broadcast. On November 25, 2008, ''[[Greatest Remixes]]'' was released. This compilation album includes 15 songs from previous Good Charlotte albums remixed by other artists such as [[Metro Station (band)|Metro Station]], [[Junior Sanchez]], [[William Beckett (singer)|William Beckett]] from [[The Academy Is...]], [[Patrick Stump]] from [[Fall Out Boy]], and [[The White Tie Affair]] featuring Mat Devine of [[Kill Hannah]]. === ''Cardiology'' and hiatus (2009–2011) === [[File:Good Charlotte in SarreBrück - 2011.jpg|thumb|Good Charlotte performing in 2011.]] Good Charlotte's fifth album, with the help of former Dear Christie lead singer Adam Markin, was released on November 2, 2010. The album, which was released nearly 6 weeks later than anticipated due to Markin's constant battle with HPV, was an immediate success. Describing the sound to MTV news, [[Joel Madden]] said it would sound a lot like [[Blink-182]].{{cite news |author=James Montgomery |others=Tim Kash |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1599560/20081117/good_charlotte.jhtml |title=Good Charlotte Fill Blink-182's Void On Next LP, Tide Fans Over With Remix Album |publisher=MTV |date=November 18, 2008 |accessdate=August 19, 2011 |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20081231221959/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1599560/20081117/good_charlotte.jhtml |archivedate=2008-12-31 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://www.goodcharlotte.com/profiles/blogs/believe-in-zero |title=Believe in Zero |publisher=Goodcharlotte.com |date=November 21, 2008 |accessdate=August 19, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212180954/http://goodcharlotte.com/profiles/blogs/believe-in-zero |archivedate=February 12, 2009}} [[Joel Madden]] went on to say in the same MTV interview that "There's nothing dance-y on the record, though, at all, which is different from our last one," further implying a movement away from the sound of ''[[Good Morning Revival]]''. On December 3, 2008 [[Kerrang!]] magazine announced that Good Charlotte would be releasing its fifth studio album, ''[[Cardiology (album)|Cardiology]]'' in 2009. The title of which, according to Joel, comes from the lyrical content of the album, which he explained is "all connected to the heart". Madden also added that the band had already written 20 songs for the new album, and are said to be heading back to their pop-punk roots. On January 24, 2010 Good Charlotte announced that the band had finished the album, but were going to completely scrap it and record with a different producer, [[Don Gilmore (producer)|Don Gilmore]], who also produced the band's first and fourth records, ''[[Good Charlotte (album)|Good Charlotte]]'' and ''Good Morning Revival''.{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/don-gilmore-mn0000798368 |title=Don Gilmore credits |website=AllMusic |accessdate=2014-01-02 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905030038/http://www.allmusic.com/artist/don-gilmore-mn0000798368 |archivedate=2012-09-05 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://goodcharlotte.com/profiles/blogs/cardiology-1 |title=Cardiology Update Stu Deeeee Ooohhhhh Studio. |publisher=Good Charlotte |date=January 19, 2010 |accessdate=August 19, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100123175045/http://goodcharlotte.com/profiles/blogs/cardiology-1 |archivedate=January 23, 2010}} The band released its first single "[[Like It's Her Birthday]]" featuring [[Tonight Alive]]{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0IX798vJnxw |title=Good Charlotte – Like it's her Birthday FEAT: Tonight Alive. |publisher=YouTube |date=November 1, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130522114342/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0IX798vJnxw&gl=US&hl=en |archivedate=2013-05-22 |deadurl=no}} from the new album on August 24, 2010. The band posted the song online August 5, 2010, and wrote on its website that if the video of the song received more than 100,000 views, the band would post another song from the album. The video reached 100,000 views on August 15, 2010 and the band released "Counting the Days" as a video on its YouTube channel and announced that it will be the second single from the album. The music video for "[[Like It's Her Birthday]]" has cameos from [[The Maine (band)|The Maine]]'s lead singer John O'Callaghan and guitarist Kennedy Brock and [[Boys Like Girls]]' lead singer [[Martin Johnson (musician)|Martin Johnson]], and guitarist [[Paul DiGiovanni]]. On November 5, 2010, Good Charlotte's former label, [[Sony Music]], released a ''[[Greatest Hits (Good Charlotte album)|Greatest Hits]]'' compilation for Australia, spanning 16 singles from the band's four studio albums released on that label. The compilation was later released in the US on January 6, 2011, and in Japan on February 16, 2011. On September 13, 2010, it was announced that Good Charlotte will be headlining the 2011 Kerrang! Relentless Tour, with supporting acts [[Four Year Strong]], [[Framing Hanley]], and [[The Wonder Years (band)|The Wonder Years]]. On March 3, 2011, Good Charlotte went on tour with [[This Century]] and [[Forever The Sickest Kids]] throughout North America.{{cite web |title=Cardiology Tour |url=http://www.pollstar.com/blogs/news/archive/2011/01/14/753097.aspx |accessdate=April 11, 2011 |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20110116210923/http://www.pollstar.com/blogs/news/archive/2011/01/14/753097.aspx |archivedate=2011-01-16 |deadurl=no}} In June 2011 Good Charlotte set out on a U.S. tour co-headlining with [[Yellowcard]] and opening act [[Runner Runner (band)|Runner Runner]]. In June 2011 on an interview with Punkvideosrock.com Billy and Paul stated they were in the process of planning tours for the next 5 years.{{cite web |title=Good Charlotte Interview w/ Robert Herrera |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0txqdtYnrIQ |publisher=Punkvideosrock.com |accessdate=June 15, 2011 |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20140104030359/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0txqdtYnrIQ |archivedate=2014-01-04 |deadurl=no}} On September 1, 2011, Good Charlotte announced a hiatus via interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', but [[The Madden Brothers]] released a free mix tape in October 2011 titled ''[[Before — Volume One]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/good-charlotte--2/58978 |title=Good Charlotte announce plans to go on hiatus | News |work=[[NME]] |date=September 1, 2011 |accessdate=November 8, 2011 |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20140103043632/http://www.nme.com/news/good-charlotte--2/58978 |archivedate=2014-01-03 |deadurl=no}}and their debut album ''[[Greetings From California]]'' was released in September 2014, which featured Good Charlotte drummer [[Dean Butterworth]] as session performer. === Reformation and ''Youth Authority'' (2015–present) === On November 3, 2015 the band announced an end to the hiatus through ''[[Alternative Press]]''.{{cite web|last1=Sharp|first1=Tyler|title=Good Charlotte Are Back! #WelcomeBackGC|url=http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/good_charlotte_are_back_welcomebackgc#.VjjlZbFvx1U.facebook|website=AltPress.com|publisher=Alternative Press|accessdate=6 November 2015|archivedate=6 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151106004549/http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/good_charlotte_are_back_welcomebackgc|date=6 November 2015}} On November 5, 2015, the band released a single, "Makeshift Love".{{cite web|last1=Hingle|first1=James|title=Good Charlotte Return, Announce New Single|url=http://www.kerrang.com/37585/good-charlotte-return-announce-new-single/|website=Kerrang.com|publisher=Kerrang|accessdate=6 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151106004806/http://www.kerrang.com/37585/good-charlotte-return-announce-new-single/|archivedate=6 November 2015|date=6 November 2015}}{{cite Today!|url=http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/good_charlotte_to_release_makeshift_love_single_today|website=AltPress.com|publisher=Alternative Press|accessdate=6 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151106004853/http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/good_charlotte_to_release_makeshift_love_single_today|archivedate=6 November 2015}} A music video for "Makeshift Love" featuring [[Mikey Way]] and [[John Feldmann]] was released on November 13, 2015.{{cite web|last1=Hingle|first1=James|title=The New Good Charlotte Music Video Features Mikey Way|url=http://www.kerrang.com/37841/the-new-good-charlotte-video-features-mikey-way/|website=Kerrang.com|publisher=Kerrang!|accessdate=13 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151113165959/http://www.kerrang.com/37841/the-new-good-charlotte-video-features-mikey-way/|archivedate=13 November 2015|date=13 November 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Hall|first1=Mackenzie|title=Good Charlotte Release Music Video for "Makeshift Love"|url=http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/good_charlotte_release_music_video_for_makeshift_love1|website=AltPress.com|publisher=Alternative Press|accessdate=13 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151113170014/http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/good_charlotte_release_music_video_for_makeshift_love1|archivedate=13 November 2015|date=13 November 2015}} The band performed its first show since its reformation on November 19, 2015, at [[Troubadour (West Hollywood, California)|The Troubadour]] in [[West Hollywood, California]].{{cite web|last1=Sharp|first1=Tyler|title=This is the Anthem: Live Updates from Good Charlotte's Comeback Show!|url=http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/this_is_the_anthem_live_updates_from_good_charlottes_comeback_show|website=AltPress.com|publisher=Alternative Press|accessdate=20 November 2015|date=19 November 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Sharp|first1=Tyler|title=Good Charlotte Announce Comeback Show!|url=http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/good_charlotte_announce_comeback_show|website=AltPress.com|publisher=Alternative Press|accessdate=6 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151106005312/http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/good_charlotte_announce_comeback_show|archivedate=6 November 2015|date=6 November 2015}} The band is due to support [[All Time Low]] on the UK and Ireland leg of the Back to the Future Hearts tour in 2016. Whilst on tour with All Time Low, Joel Madden announced that Good Charlotte would tour once again during the autumn. The group is set to release their sixth studio album, ''[[Youth Authority]]'', on July 15, 2016, with guest appearances from Kellin Quinn of [[Sleeping with Sirens]] and [[Simon Neil]] of [[Biffy Clyro]]. The album release date was announced on March 30, 2016, with the album title and art following several days later.{{cite web|last1=Sharp|first1=Tyler|title=Good Charlotte to drop comeback album days before Warped Tour headlining shows|url=http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/good_charlotte_to_drop_comeback_album_days_before_warped_tour_headlining_sh|website=Alternative Press|publisher=Alternative Press|accessdate=30 March 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160330192116/http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/good_charlotte_to_drop_comeback_album_days_before_warped_tour_headlining_sh|archivedate=30 March 2016|date=30 March 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Greenwald|first1=Morgan|title=Good Charlotte Announces Mini-Tour, Sixth Album After Six-Year Hiatus|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/7256333/good-charlotte-mini-tour-sixth-album|website=Billboard|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=15 March 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315174243/http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/7256333/good-charlotte-mini-tour-sixth-album|archivedate=15 March 2016|date=14 March 2016}} == Activism == Billy Martin is an active vegetarian, and won [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]]'s vegetarian of the year. In the past the band actively supported PETA's [[animal rights]] campaigns. Members of the group recorded a track, "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous", on PETA's ''Liberation'' CD and appeared at PETA's 25th Anniversary Gala and Humanitarian Awards Show.{{cite web |url=http://www.peta2.com/outthere/o-galawrapup.asp |title=PETA's 25th Anniversary Gala and Humanitarian Awards Show |publisher=Peta2.com |accessdate=August 19, 2011 |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20120327034334/http://www.peta2.com/outthere/o-galawrapup.asp |archivedate=2012-03-27 |deadurl=no}} Group members have also demonstrated against [[KFC]]'s treatment of chickens.{{cite web |url=http://www.peta2.com/heroes/good-charlotte-take-on-kfc/ |title=Good Charlotte Take On KFC |publisher=Peta2.com |accessdate=December 15, 2012 |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20120806083503/http://www.peta2.com/heroes/good-charlotte-take-on-kfc/ |archivedate=2012-08-06 |deadurl=no}} In 2012 and 2013, band members heavily promoted [[Kentucky Fried Chicken]] in a series of Australian television commercials, leading to charges of hypocrisy. The Madden Brothers appeared in an episode of ''[[Australia's Got Talent]]'' where their act was eating KFC to set a [[Guinness World Record]].{{cite web |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/sold-out-for-a-poultry-sum-20121212-2b8f2.html |title=Sold out for a poultry sum |publisher=Brisbane Times |date=December 12, 2012 |author=Daniel Burt |accessdate=December 15, 2012 |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20140104030726/http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/sold-out-for-a-poultry-sum-20121212-2b8f2.html |archivedate=2014-01-04 |deadurl=no}} Joel Madden was also named a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador in 2007 and continues work with UNICEF and other children's organizations with his Richie-Madden Children's foundation. The group has been a big supporter of the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention. Good Charlotte, as well as The Madden Brothers, have been active supporters of The Make-A-Wish Foundation. The twins have also posed for the YouthAIDS [[Aldo Groupe|Aldo]] "Aldo Fights AIDS" dog tag campaign. ==Band members== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;Current members * [[Joel Madden]] – [[Lead vocalist|lead vocals]] (1995–present); [[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]] (1995–1998) * [[Benji Madden]] – [[lead guitar]], [[Backing vocalist|backing vocals]] (1995–present) * [[Paul Thomas (bassist)|Paul Thomas]] – [[bass guitar]] (1995–present) * [[Billy Martin (guitarist)|Billy Martin]] – [[rhythm guitar]], keyboards (1998–present) * [[Dean Butterworth]] – [[Drum kit|drums]], [[Percussion instrument|percussion]] (2005–present) {{col-2}} ;Former members * [[Aaron Escolopio]] – drums, percussion (1995–2001) * Chris Wilson – drums, percussion (2003–2005) ;Session studio musicians * [[Josh Freese]] – drums, percussion on ''The Young and the Hopeless'' (2002) * [[David Campbell (composer)|David Campbell]] – [[String (music)|string arrangements]], string conducting on ''Good Charlotte'' (2000), ''The Young and the Hopeless'' (2002) and ''The Chronicles of Life and Death'' (2004) {{col-end}} ===Timeline===

content:

The '''Pukhtoonkhwa Mazdoor Kissan Party''' was a [[Pushtun]] nationalist [[political party]] in [[Pakistan]]. It was formed by [[Sher Ali Bacha]] in 1979, as a split from the [[Maoism|Maoist]] [[Mazdoor Kisan Party]]. In 1989 the party merged into the [[Pukhtunkhwa Milli Awami Party]].
