title: Brockway Mountain Drive
content:
{{bots|deny=Citation bot}}{{use mdy dates|date=December 2014}}
{{Infobox road
|state=MI
|type=CR
|county=Keweenaw
|header_type=historic
|name=Brockway Mountain Drive
|marker_image=[[File:Brockway sign.svg|250px|alt=A graphic representation of the brown wooden sign for Brockway Mountain Drive]]
|map_notes=Brockway Mountain Drive highlighted in red
|map_alt=Brockway Mountain Drive runs east–west parallel to the southern shores of Lake Superior along Michigan's Keweenaw Peninsula
|maint=the [[Keweenaw County Road Commission]]
|length_mi=8.883
|length_ref=<ref name=PRFA/>
|established={{start date|1933|10|14}}<ref name=lavanway-2010>{{cite book |last= LaVanway |first= Paul |year= 2010 |title= The Brockway Mountain Drive Story |edition= 2nd |location= Copper Harbor, MI |publisher= Keweenaw County Historical Society |pages= 1–2, 6, 9–11 |isbn= 978-0-9823451-0-8 |oclc= 751396113}}</ref>
|restrictions=Closed to vehicular traffic in winter
|direction_a=West
|terminus_a={{jct|state=MI|M|26}} near [[Eagle Harbor, Michigan|Eagle Harbor]]
|direction_b=East
|terminus_b={{jct|state=MI|M|26}} in [[Copper Harbor, Michigan|Copper Harbor]]
|counties=[[Keweenaw County, Michigan|Keweenaw]]
}}

'''Brockway Mountain Drive''' is an {{convert|8.883|mi|km|adj=on}} [[scenic highway|scenic roadway]] just west of [[Copper Harbor, Michigan|Copper Harbor]] in the [[Upper Peninsula of Michigan]] in the United States. Drivers can access the road from state highway [[M-26 (Michigan highway)|M-26]] on either end near [[Eagle Harbor, Michigan|Eagle Harbor]] to the west or Copper Harbor to the east in the [[Keweenaw Peninsula]]. The drive runs along the ridge of '''Brockway Mountain''' on the [[Keweenaw Fault]] and climbs to {{convert|1320|ft|m|0}} above sea level, {{convert|720|ft|m}} above the surface of [[Lake Superior]]. Several viewpoints along the route allow for panoramas of Copper Harbor, Lake Superior, and undeveloped woodland. On a clear day, [[Isle Royale]] is visible approximately {{convert|50|mi|km}} in distance from the top of the mountain.

Brockway Mountain was named for Daniel D. Brockway, one of the pioneer residents of the area. The road was constructed by the county road commission with funding through [[Great Depression|Depression]]-era work programs in 1933. It was briefly used as a connection for the parallel state highway after it opened. Since it opened, Brockway Mountain Drive has been recognized nationally and locally in several media outlets for its picturesque qualities, usually in profiles of [[Keweenaw County, Michigan|Keweenaw County]], the Upper Peninsula or other scenic drives.

== Route description ==
The road can be accessed from either Eagle Harbor or Copper Harbor and serves as a scenic loop off M-26. The western end starts at M-26 near Lake Bailey and Agate Harbor. Brockway Mountain Drive ascends along the ridgeline of the Keweenaw Fault. Immediately south of the road, Upson Creek runs parallel to the cliff face as it drains Lake Upson.<ref name=googleBMD/> Two and a half miles (4.0 km) <!-- {{convert|2+1/2|mi|km|spell=in}} --> from the western end, there is a parking area for the Oren Krumm Trail, part of the Brockway Mountain Audubon Sanctuary.<ref name=BMAS>{{cite web |author= Keweenaw Convention & Visitors Bureau |url=http://www.keweenaw.info/details_378_brockwaymountainaudubonsanctuary.aspx |title=Brockway Mountain Audubon Sanctuary |publisher=Keweenaw Convention & Visitors Bureau |year=2001 |accessdate=January 26, 2011 |archiveurl=http://replay.waybackmachine.org/20090206220535/http://keweenaw.info/details_378_brockwaymountainaudubonsanctuary.aspx |archivedate=February 6, 2009}}</ref> The drive is lined with low stone walls, built as part of the original construction of the roadway.<ref name=NSBP/>

[[File:Brockway Mountain Lake Superior.jpg|thumb|left|View of Lake Superior from Brockway Mountain with information signage|alt=There are wooden information signs in the foreground, left and Lake Superior in the distance beyond the top of Brockway Mountain.]]
Upon reaching the top of the mountain, drivers are greeted with a full panoramic view of the surrounding area, allowing views of Lake Superior, Copper Harbor, Eagle Harbor and the surrounding lakes and forests.  Freighters occasionally can be seen traversing Lake Superior, and on clear days [[Isle Royale]] can be spotted nearly {{convert|50|mi|km}} in the distance.<ref name=hunt>{{cite book |last1=Hunt |first1=Mary |last2=Hunt |first2=Don |chapter= Brockway Mountain Drive |year=2007 |title=Hunts' Guide to Michigan's Upper Peninsula |publisher= Midwestern Guides |location=Albion, MI  |url=http://hunts-upguide.com/ |chapterurl= http://hunts-upguide.com/copper_harbor_brockway_mountain_drive.html |accessdate=February 21, 2008 |lastauthoramp=y}}</ref>

Continuing eastward, the drive descends down the mountain toward Copper Harbor. The roadway twists and turns as it alternately climbs and descends several smaller hills along the ridgeline. Along the drive, several viewpoints provide the opportunity to pull off and take in the surroundings. A few of them lie directly adjacent to the face of the bluff where the mountain quickly rises from the surrounding land. Near the eastern end, there are two sharp [[hairpin turn]]s, the first of which has a scenic overlook and parking area. This spot overlooks Copper Harbor and the nearby [[Copper Country Trail]] National Scenic Byway portion of [[U.S. Route 41 in Michigan|US Highway 41]] (US 41) just to the east. From here, the road makes its steep descent down from the ridge, through the second turn and ends at M-26 on the western edge of town.<ref name=googleBMD>{{google maps |title=Overview Map of Brockway Mountain Drive |url=http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&saddr=Brockway+Mountain+Drive+%26+M-26,+Copper+Harbor,+MI&daddr=47.466629,-87.988815+to:Brockway+Mountain+Drive+%26+M-26,+Eagle+Harbor,+MI&hl=en&geocode=&mra=dpe&mrcr=0&mrsp=1&sz=12&via=1&sll=47.52207,-88.010445&sspn=0.147455,0.22934&ie=UTF8&t=p&z=12  |accessdate=August 2, 2008}}</ref>

[[File:BrockwayMountainPeak.jpg|thumb|right|Peak of Brockway Mountain|alt=Photograph of]]
This road is one of the highest scenic roadways [[above sea level]] in the US between the [[Rocky Mountains|Rocky]] and [[Allegheny Mountains|Allegheny]] mountains.<ref name=hunt/><ref>{{cite book |last1=Storm |first1=Roger E. |last2=Wedzel |first2=Susan M. |title= Hiking Michigan |year=2009 |location=Champaign, IL |publisher=[[Human Kinetics (publisher)|Human Kinetics]] |page=57 |isbn= 978-0-7360-7507-7 |oclc= 251227972 |edition=2nd |lastauthoramp=y }}</ref> During the winter, Brockway Mountain Drive is closed to cars as the [[Keweenaw County Road Commission]] does not plow the road; instead the drive is used as a snowmobile trail.<ref name=hunt/> According to the commission, 200 vehicles per day use the roadway on average.<ref name=kcrcadt>{{cite report |last= Patrick |first= Gregg M. |date= August 2007 |title= Traffic Counts |location= Mohawk, MI |publisher= Keweenaw County Road Commission}}</ref> There are no posted speed limits along the roadway, however in the words of a former Keweenaw County Sheriff's Department deputy, "the nature and design of the road was such that the 'problem' of people driving too fast ... was basically 'self-correcting'."<ref name=lavanway-2010/>

== History ==
[[File:West Bluff summit view, 1933.png|thumb|left|View of Lakes Upson and Bailey before construction of the road, 1933|alt=Photograph of the]]
Brockway Mountain is a {{convert|1320|ft|m|adj=on}} volcanic landform on the [[Keweenaw Peninsula]] of Michigan about {{convert|5|mi|km|spell=in}} west of Copper Harbor.<ref name=MJ71>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CohQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uhEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5942,3129650&dq=brockway+mountain&hl=en |title=Alone, Not Lonely on his Mountain |work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |first=Dan |last=Patrinos |date=January 16, 1971 |page=3 |accessdate= January 27, 2011 |issn= 1082-8850 |id= {{oclc| 55506548| 464373546}} }}</ref>  The top of the mountain is {{convert|720|ft|m}} above the level of Lake Superior.<ref name=NYTA>{{cite book |editor-first= John W. |editor-last= Wright |year=2007 |title=The New York Times Almanac |edition=2007 |publisher=[[Penguin Books]] |location= New York |isbn= 0-14-303820-6 |oclc= 75276830 |page=64}}<!--According to the almanac, Lake Superior is 600 feet above sea level.--></ref> The peak was named for Daniel D. Brockway, local pioneer settler, postmaster and state road commissioner. Brockway moved to Copper Harbor in 1846 at the beginning of the area's copper boom. He built the first permanent structure in the community, a hostelry named The Brockway House, which was used by the miners and scientists in the area. By the time of his death on May 9, 1899, the ridge west of town had been named in his honor.<ref name=barnett/>

A road to the summit of Brockway Mountain was first proposed in the 1920s by [[Warren H. Manning]], a renowned landscape architect. Manning was in the Keweenaw at the time to design Agassiz Park in [[Calumet, Michigan|Calumet]] and suggested the road while visiting the area. The road was designed in 1932 with three different options considered. The first involved the construction of the current road from near the Silver River on the west to the summit. It followed a route used by the previous [[U.S. Route 41 in Michigan#Military Road|Military Road]] that connected [[Fort Wilkins]] to [[Fort Howard (Wisconsin)|Fort Howard]]; traffic would have to turn around to descend Brockway Mountain. Another option included a route from the summit southwest across the Upson Creek Valley to a second summit on the nearby Mount Lookout, a total of about {{convert|16|mi|km}}. The third option was that of the current route down the mountain to the west.<ref name=lavanway-2010/>

[[File:Brockway Mountain Drive western end, 1933-34.png|thumb|Original, "ball bearing" gravel road surface, 1933–34|alt=Photograph showing the]]
Construction of Brockway Mountain Drive began in early 1933 by the Keweenaw County Road Commission with federal highway funding designed to provide meaningful work to the many copper miners who became unemployed during the [[Great Depression in the United States|Great Depression]]. Rather than provide welfare, the government provided work for the jobless.<ref name=barnett/> The [[Reconstruction Finance Corporation]] was the agency on the federal level responsible for the project.<ref name=KNHP>{{cite conference |title= Keweenaw County in the Great Depression: Work Relief, the Dole, and Long-Range Public Investment |first= Paul |last= LaVanway |date= September 22, 2011 |conference= Fourth Thursday in History  |publisher= [[Keweenaw National Historical Park]] |location= Calumet, MI }}</ref> Up to 300 laborers were employed for a wage of 25[[Cent (currency)|¢]]/hr (equivalent to ${{formatprice|{{inflation|US|0.25|1933|{{inflation-year|US-NGDPPC}}|r=2}}}}/hr in {{inflation-year|US-NGDPPC}}{{inflation-fn|US}}).<!--This is set up so that the two inflation adjustments will always adjust to the same year, even when they have different series end years.--> The work required to build the road was carried out by manual labor, with the assistance of a team of horses,<ref name=barnett/> in a project designed to maximize the numbers of men employed.<ref name=lavanway-2008>{{cite journal |last=LaVanway |first=Paul |date= July–August 2008 |title= At the Top of Michigan—the Village of Copper Harbor |journal= [[Michigan History magazine|Michigan History]] |location=Lansing, MI |publisher=[[Michigan Department of State]] |issn= 0026-2196 |oclc= 220951644 |volume=94 |issue=4 |page=54 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-185166421.html |accessdate= February 26, 2011}} {{subscription required}}</ref> The grading and leveling of the road surface was done by hand; no survey instruments were used to level the roadway.<ref name=DMG-1986-06-07>{{cite news |last= |first= |date= June 6, 1986 |title= |work= [[The Daily Mining Gazette]] |location= Houghton, MI |page= |oclc= 9940134 }}</ref> The road was opened for public use that October 14,<ref name=lavanway-2010/> at a preliminary cost of $30,000 (equivalent to ${{formatprice|{{inflation|US-NGDPPC|30000|1933|r=-3}}}} in {{inflation-year|US-NGDPPC}}{{inflation-fn|US-NGDPPC|lastauthoramp=yes}}).<ref name=barnett/> That same year, the Skytop Inn opened on top of the mountain.<ref name=hunt/> During 1934, additional work was done to the roadway to build the stone walls. Motorists were restricted to one-way traffic, and the road was only open to the public on Sundays and holidays.<ref name=CN>{{cite news |title= Local Briefs |date= May 24, 1934 |work= The Calumet News |page= 2 |oclc= 14768241}}</ref> In the interim, the road was temporarily used as a connection between completed segments of the parallel state highway, numbered [[M-129 (Michigan highway)|M-129]] at the time. This highway, now part of M-26, was built starting in July 1933 but was not completed through the area until October 1934.<ref name=barnett>{{cite book |last= Barnett |first= LeRoy |title= A Drive Down Memory Lane: The Named State and Federal Highways of Michigan |publisher=Priscilla Press |location= Allegan Forest, MI  |year= 2004 |isbn= 1-886167-24-9 |oclc= 57425393 |pages=39–40 }}</ref> The KCRC declared the road initially finished on June 14, 1935, at a cost of $40,000 (equivalent to ${{formatprice|{{inflation|US-NGDPPC|40000|1935|r=-3}}}} in {{inflation-year|US-NGDPPC}}{{inflation-fn|US-NGDPPC|lastauthoramp=yes}})<ref name=KCRC>{{cite book |last1= Hartman |first= William F. (President) |last2= Lampi |first2= Charles (Clerk) |chapter= Adjourned Meeting on June 14, 1935 |title= Minutes of the Board |location= Mohawk, MI |publisher= Keweenaw County Road Commission |date= July 12, 1935<!--Meeting minutes are "published" once approved at the next meeting--> |pages= 403–4 |lastauthoramp=y}}</ref>

[[File:Skytop Inn, late 1930s.png|thumb|left|Original Skytop Inn, late 1930s|alt=Photograph of Adrian Tousigant standing in the doorway of the]]
According to historian LeRoy Barnett, "this county highway quickly became one of the most popular motoring destinations in the Midwest."<ref name=barnett2>{{cite journal |last=Barnett |first=LeRoy |date= November–December 2001 |title= Brockway Mountain Drive |journal=Michigan History |location=Lansing, MI |publisher= Michigan Department of State |issn=0026-2196 |oclc= 220951644 |volume=85 |issue=6 |page=30 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-163049807.html |accessdate= February 26, 2011 |subscription= yes}}</ref> The ''[[Ironwood Daily Globe]]'' reported that in December 1938, "at least one million persons" had traveled on Brockway Mountain Drive in the first five years it was open, sparking a tourism boom in the area.<ref name=IDG>{{cite news |title= Around the Peninsula |url= http://newspaperarchive.com/daily-globe/1938-12-12/page-4/ |work= [[Ironwood Daily Globe]] |date= December 12, 1938 |page=4 |oclc= 10890811 |accessdate= May 18, 2012}}</ref> The eastern end of the roadway was paved in 1938, with the final {{convert|2|mi|km|spell=in}} done in 1940. The first Skytop Inn was built at the summit of Brockway Mountain in 1935. A replacement structure, the one that stands on the summit today, was built in 1965. During the first few winters of 1946/47 and 1947/48, a ski hill was operated down the roadway on the western end.<ref name=lavanway-2010/>

In February 2013, [[Eagle Harbor Township, Michigan|Eagle Harbor Township]] purchased {{convert|320|acre|ha}} at the top of Brockway Mountain with plans to refit the Skytop Inn to serve as a visitors center.<ref name=purchase>{{cite news |title= Eagle Harbor Township Buys 320 Acres at Brockway |url= http://www.mininggazette.com/page/content.detail/id/528864/Eagle-Harbor-Township-buys-320-acres-at-Brockway.html?nav=5006 |date= February 16, 2013 |first= Garrett |last= Neese |work= The Daily Mining Gazette |location= Houghton, MI |accessdate= December 1, 2013}}</ref> The building was the oldest gift shop in Keweenaw County and owned by the same family from the time of its construction<ref>{{cite book |first= Jennifer |last= Billock |year= 2013 |title= Keweenaw County |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=WNhgAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA111&lpg=PA111  |series= Images of America|location= Charleston, SC |publisher= Arcadia Publishing |page= 111 |isbn= 978-1-4671-1123-2 |oclc= 887183748 |via= [[Google Books]] }}</ref> until it was sold in 2013.<ref name=purchase/> The following August, Governor [[Rick Snyder]] helped to dedicate the summit as part of the Keweenaw Coastal Wildlife Corridor, a protected area in the raptors' annual migration flight path.<ref name=dedicated>{{cite news |title= Brockway Mtn. Summit Dedicated |date= August 14, 2013 |first= Garrett |last= Neese |work= The Daily Mining Gazette |location= Houghton, MI |url= http://www.mininggazette.com/page/content.detail/id/530851/Brockway-Mtn--summit-dedicated.html |accessdate= December 1, 2013}}</ref> The area is now owned by the township after assistance by [[The Nature Conservancy]] and local donors.<ref>{{cite news |last= Blakely |first= Sarah |date= August 14, 2013 |title= Governor Snyder at the top of the UP Brockway Mtn |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PsX0CPhTzE4 |work= TV6 Early News |location= Negaunee, MI |publisher= [[WLUC-TV]] |access-date= April 15, 2015 |via= [[YouTube]] }}</ref>

== Scenic opportunities ==
[[File:Brockway Mountain Drive east overlook.jpg|thumb|View of Copper Harbor (left) and Lake Fanny Hooe (right) from the easternmost overlook|alt=Photograph of the]]
During the spring, particularly in April, hawks migrate along the length of the Keweenaw Peninsula headed across Lake Superior. They flock together along the cliffs and ridges of Brockway Mountain. The top of the mountain is a semi-[[alpine climate]] with strong winds, and guide books advise visitors to bring windbreaker jackets, even in the summer.<ref name=hunt/> The peak is also known as an excellent star-gazing location because there are no electric lights to interrupt the darkness.<ref name=SPG>{{cite web |author= Copper Harbor, Michigan |url=http://www.copperharbor.org/brockway_s.html |title=Brockway Mountain Drive |work= Summer Planning Guide |publisher=Copper Harbor, Michigan |date= |accessdate=January 27, 2011 |archiveurl=http://replay.waybackmachine.org/20090525234453/http://www.copperharbor.org/brockway_s.html |archivedate=May 25, 2009}}</ref> The surrounding mountainsides are privately owned, mostly by [[Champion International Paper]]. The company receives reduced taxes in exchange for keeping the land open for recreational uses. The [[Michigan Nature Association]] owns {{convert|200|acre}} of property on Brockway Mountain itself. There are over 700 species of flowers including [[trillium]] and [[orchids]]. The peak bloom is in June, and some of the wildflowers on display are not found elsewhere in the state.<ref name=hunt/> ''Motorcycle Cruiser'' magazine featured a piece on Copper Harbor in February 2010 that suggested visiting Brockway Mountain at dawn saying that "the vista at the peak is amazing and it's worth the early morning rise."<ref name=motorcyle>{{cite journal |last=Calabro |first=Mike |title=Just One Road: Copper Harbor Circle Tour, Michigan |journal= Motorcycle Cruiser |issn= 1525-772X |oclc= 669912268 |date= February 2010 |volume=15 |issue=1 |page=90 |url= http://www.motorcyclecruiser.com/rideanddest/1002_crup_copper_harbor_circle_tour_michigan/index.html |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/67kcJ3PKS |archivedate= May 18, 2012 |deadurl= no}}</ref> The area is renowned as a fall foliage destination;<ref name=Today/> color season starts by the second week of September and ends in October.<ref name=hunt/>

== Awards and recognition ==
Many locales in the Keweenaw Peninsula are frequently praised for their beauty and pristine appearances and Brockway Mountain Drive is no exception.  The road has been recognized in numerous publications, dating back to the 1950s. The ''[[Milwaukee Sentinel]]'' profiled the "famous Brockway Mountain Drive" in 1956 in an article about a tourism boom to the region.<ref name=MkeSentinel>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9u8pAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-Q8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6775,671765&dq=brockway+mountain&hl=en |title=Tourist Boom in Keweenaw |work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|Milwaukee Sentinel]] |date= September 2, 1956 |page=4A |accessdate=January 26, 2011 |issn= 1052-4479 |oclc= 11723897}}</ref> More attention was focused on the roadway when Milwaukee's other newspaper, the ''[[Milwaukee Journal]]'', spotlighted the region in 1961 stating, "the road along the Brockway Mountain fault follows the Keweenaw Peninsula  {{convert|700|ft|m|abbr=on|disp=x| [|]}} above Lake Superior, past ghost copper mines [toward] restored Fort Wilkins".<ref name=MkeJournal>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MN8jAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4iYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7188,3403036&dq=brockway+mountain&hl=en |last=Kienitz |first=Richard C. |title=Hiawatha Land Vast Playground |work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|Milwaukee Journal]] |date=August 17, 1961 |page=24 |accessdate=January 26, 2011 |issn= 1052-4452 |oclc= 298956108}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' had similar praise in 1962, saying "a side trip that should not be missed is the Brockway Mountain Drive ... for a panoramic view of the forest and the blue waters of Lake Superior."<ref name=NYT>{{cite news |last=Stetson |first=Damon |title= Circling Michigan's Scenic Upper Peninsula |url= http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10E11F9385A15768FDDA00A94DF405B828AF1D3 |date=January 29, 1962 |work=[[The New York Times]] |page=249 |accessdate=February 21, 2008 |issn= 0362-4331 |oclc= 1645522 |subscription= yes}}</ref> The ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' called the overlook "breathtaking" in 1986,<ref name=CT>{{cite news |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24932157.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+24%2C+1986&author=Robert+Wolf&pub=Chicago+Tribune+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&edition=&startpage=8&desc=MIDWEST+ON+VERGE+OF+BLAZING+COLORS |last=Wolf |first=Robert |title=Midwest on Verge of Blazing Colors |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date= Aug 24, 1986 |page=8 |accessdate=January 26, 2011 |issn= 1085-6706 |id= {{oclc| 7960243| 232606698}} |via= [[ProQuest]] Archiver |subscription= yes}}</ref> and the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' said that views from Brockway "rival[ed] any in New England" in 1990.<ref name=puhala>{{cite news |last= Puhala |first= Bob  |title= Color Caravan: Driving The Midwest's Best Fall-Foliage Routes |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4012904.html |work= [[Chicago Sun-Times]] |date= August 19, 1990 |accessdate= May 18, 2012 |issn= 1553-8478 |id= {{oclc| 191717467| 51500916}} |via= [[HighBeam]] |subscription= yes}}</ref> The ''[[St. Paul Pioneer Press|Pioneer Press]]'' of St. Paul profiled the area in 2005 saying that the tourists "cruise along Brockway Mountain Drive, renowned for fall color."<ref name=pp05>{{cite news |last= Gauper |first=Beth |title= On Lake Superior: An Isolated Peninsula Yields up all Sorts of Riches |work=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press|Pioneer Press]] |date= July 5, 2005 |location= St. Paul, MN |page= F1 |issn= 0892-1083 |oclc= 21278702 }}</ref> The staff of ''MLive'', the online news presence of [[Booth Newspapers]] in Michigan, highlighted the height of the roadway, the view to Isle Royale, and the birdwatching opportunities in a profile of the area in 2007.<ref>{{cite news |author= MLive Staff |date= June 11, 2007 |url= http://blog.mlive.com/michigan_travel/2007/06/scenic_weekend_drives.html|title= Driving at 726 Feet Above Lake Superior |work= MLive |publisher= [[Booth Newspapers]] |accessdate= November 11, 2014}}</ref>

In April 1994 and April 2001, the route along US 41 and Brockway Mountain Drive was selected as "one of the best fall color views and mountain biking areas" by ''Michigan Living''.<ref name=ML94>{{cite  journal |title=Treasure Hunt: Readers Uncover State's Best |journal=Michigan Living |volume=76 |issue=10 |date=April 1994 |issn= 0735-1798}}</ref><ref name=ML01>{{cite journal |title=Michigan's Best: Treasure Awards 2001 |journal=Michigan Living |volume=83 |issue=7 |pages=24–29 |date=April 2001 |issn= 0735-1798}}</ref> It was also named the "most beautiful bike ride in the United States" by ''[[Bicycling (magazine)|Bicycling]]'' magazine in February 1995.<ref name=Bicycling>{{cite journal |last=Sandretto |first=Peter, Jr. |title= The Keweenaw Peninsula, Michigan |journal=[[Bicycling (magazine)|Bicycling]] |date=February 1995 |volume=36 |issue=2 |pages= 56–7 |issn= 0006-2073}}</ref> The ''[[Star Tribune]]'' in Minneapolis said that a visit to the drive "is worth the whole trip by itself, with a twisting road leading up to the crest, with panoramic views of fall colors."<ref name=ST>{{cite news |last=Gilbert |first=John |title= Keweenaw Peninsula; Fall Colors Undimmed |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62641077.html |date= October 6, 1996 |work =[[Star Tribune]] |location=Minneapolis |page= 6G |accessdate =February 21, 2008 |issn= 0895-2825 |oclc= 61312696 |via= HighBeam |subscription= yes}}</ref>
The drive was also included in the coverage of the [[Copper Country Trail]], a designation applied to the neighboring US 41 by the [[Federal Highway Administration]] as a part of the [[National Scenic Byway]] program.<ref name=NSBP>{{cite web |author= [[Federal Highway Administration]] |title= Brockway Mountain Drive, MI |date= |work= America's Byways |publisher= Federal Highway Administration |url= http://www.byways.org/explore/byways/13828/places/14317/ |accessdate=October 26, 2006 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xcNRvcj7 |archivedate=April 1, 2011 |deadurl= no }}</ref> [[NBC]]'s ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today]]'' featured Brockway Mountain Drive in September 2007 as part of a segment  on "great and unusual fall foliage destinations".<ref name=Today>{{cite news |first=Peter |last=Greenberg |authorlink= Peter Greenberg |title=8 Great and Unusual Fall Foliage Destinations |url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/20997833/ns/today-todaytravel/ |work=[[Today (NBC program)|Today]] |publisher=[[NBC]] |location=New York |date= September 27, 2007 |accessdate=January 27, 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w2xfnZC4 |archivedate=January 27, 2011}}</ref> In May 2010, local residents of the Upper Peninsula chose the road as the region's "favorite natural wonder" in a poll conducted by [[WLUC-TV]].<ref name=TV6>{{cite news |url=http://www.uppermichiganssource.com/news/story.aspx?id=462587 |last=Palumbo |first=Ashley |title=Seven Wonders of the UP: Brockway Mountain |work= Upper Michigan's Source |publisher= WLUC-TV |location=Negaunee, MI |date=May 26, 2010 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w1JuZ3yE |archivedate=January 26, 2011 |accessdate=January 26, 2011}}</ref>
{{Clear}}
{{Wide image|Brockway Mountain Drive Panorama.jpg|800px|View from atop Brockway Mountain|alt=An autumnal panorama from the top of Brockway Mountain with Lake Fanny Hooe and Lake Superior in the distance and Brockway Mountain Drive descending the hill}}

|blank1_info              = 1660156
|footnotes                =

'''Westwood''' is a [[census-designated place]] (CDP) in [[Lassen County, California|Lassen County]], [[California]], [[United States]]. Westwood is located 20 miles (32 km) west-southwest of [[Susanville, California|Susanville]],<ref name=CGN>{{California's Geographic Names|428-429}}</ref> at an elevation of 5,128 feet (1,563 m).<ref name=gnis /> The population was 1,647 at the 2010 census, down from 1,998 at the [[2000 United States Census|2000 census]].  Westwood is the hometown of mythical logger [[Paul Bunyan (lumberjack)|Paul Bunyan]].

==Geography==
Westwood is built upon lava flows from Cascade Mountain Range volcanoes to the north. Keddie Ridge is considered to be at the northern end of the Sierra Nevada Mountain Range.<ref>[http://patriotsdayride.com/ridecamp.html Ride Camp], Patriot's Day Endurance Rides (horses), accessed 10 March 2013</ref>

According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the CDP has a total area of {{convert|5.5|sqmi|km2}}, of which {{convert|5.4|sqmi|km2}} is land and {{convert|0.1|sqmi|km2}} (1.34%) is water.

==History==
Westwood was built by [[T. B. Walker]] to be the operations center for the [[Red River Lumber Company]] in 1913.<ref name=CGN /><ref>{{cite book|title=American Lumberman|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=cAFQAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA52|year=1920|publisher=American Lumberman|pages=2–}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mnhs.org/library/findaids/00093.xml T.B. Walker and Family: An inventory of their papers at the Minnesota Historical Society, Manuscripts Collection, accessed March 8, 2014]</ref> The first post office opened the same year.<ref name=CGN /> The Red River Lumber Company is credited as being "the world's largest electrical sawmill of the times."<ref>{{cite web|title=Lassen County History|url=http://www.cagenweb.com/lassen/his.htm|work=Lassen County, California Genweb Project|publisher=CagenWeb|accessdate=8 March 2014}}</ref>  Red River Lumber Company also operated one of the first electric railways in the state.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our History and Philosophy|url=http://shastaforests.com/history_philosophy.php|publisher=Shasta Forests Timberlands, LLC|accessdate=8 March 2014}}</ref> The mill was equipped with the most modern equipment for its time.<ref>{{cite book|title=Western Machinery and Steel World|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=-fg9AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA49|year=1921|pages=49–}}</ref>

William Laughead, an advertising copywriter who had once worked in lumber camps, took the stories of an old lumberjack and reworked them into the modern character. He sold the stories of Paul Bunyan and his Blue Ox "Babe" to the Red River Lumber Company, which published "Introducing Mr. Paul Bunyan of Westwood, California" in 1916 as an advertising pamphlet.<ref name=Laughead>{{cite web|url=http://content.wisconsinhistory.org/u?/tp,58090 |title=Complete Laughead pamphlet |publisher=Content.wisconsinhistory.org |date=1924-06-30 |accessdate=2012-10-08}}</ref> Among other things, Laughead gave the name "Babe" to the blue ox, originated the idea that Paul Bunyan and Babe were of enormous size, and created the first pictorial representation of Bunyan.<ref name=Laughead />

The Red River Lumber Company's electric mill at Westwood made wooden Venetian blinds, plywood, boxes, doors and windows which were shipped all over the U.S. and the world.<ref name ="soil">{{cite book|title=Soil Survey|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=XtDwAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA2|year=2004|publisher=U.S. Department of Agriculture|pages=2–}}</ref>  The Westwood mill set a world record in 1942 by sawing 212 million board feet.<ref name = "soil" />

Westwood High School's nickname is the Lumberjacks. Westwood had a very large indoor shopping mall as far back as the 1930s, as well as a large theater, skating rink and club for the mill workers. The town was sold in 1944 to the Fruit Growers Supply Company (sister cooperative of [[Sunkist Growers, Incorporated|Sunkist Growers]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=T. B. Walker|url=http://www.slphistory.org/history/walkertb.asp|publisher=St. Louis Park Historical Society|accessdate=2009-11-28}}</ref> The plant closed in 1956, and the town was sold to residents and developers.<ref>{{Cite news | pages = 19 | title = GHOSTS MOVE OUT: Lassen Town Booms Again Despite Lumber Mill Loss | work = Oakland Tribune | accessdate = 2015-02-14 | date = 1957-10-20 | url = http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/california/oakland/oakland-tribune/1957/10-20/page-18?tag=westwood+fruit+growers+supply&rtserp=tags/westwood?pep=fruit-growers-supply&psb=date&page=2&ndt=by&py=1950&pey=1959 }}</ref>

Westwood also had a very early form of cable television. The owner of the local variety store took it upon himself to provide television service to the community. At the time three channels were available to view in Westwood, Channel 3 the NBC affiliate in Sacramento, Channel 7 the ABC affiliate in Redding and Channel 12 the CBS affiliate in Chico. Multiple antennae were mounted outside of town and coax cable was laid up and down the allies. For a small monthly fee a home could have television service without having three separate antennae on the roof.

==Demographics==

===2010===
The [[2010 United States Census]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.census.gov/2010census/popmap/ipmtext.php?fl=06:0684928|title=2010 Census Interactive Population Search: CA - Westwood CDP|publisher=U.S. Census Bureau|accessdate=July 12, 2014}}</ref> reported that Westwood had a population of 1,647. The [[population density]] was 298.9 people per square mile (115.4/km²). The racial makeup of Westwood was 1,430 (86.8%) [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 3 (0.2%) [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 104 (6.3%) [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 10 (0.6%) [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 2 (0.1%) [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 49 (3.0%) from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 49 (3.0%) from two or more races.  [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 179 persons (10.9%).

The Census reported that 1,647 people (100% of the population) lived in households, 0 (0%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 0 (0%) were institutionalized.

There were 715 households, out of which 219 (30.6%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 299 (41.8%) were [[marriage|opposite-sex married couples]] living together, 87 (12.2%) had a female householder with no husband present, 51 (7.1%) had a male householder with no wife present.  There were 65 (9.1%) [[POSSLQ|unmarried opposite-sex partnerships]], and 3 (0.4%) [[same-sex partnerships|same-sex married couples or partnerships]]. 223 households (31.2%) were made up of individuals and 92 (12.9%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.30.  There were 437 [[family (U.S. Census)|families]] (61.1% of all households); the average family size was 2.87.

The population was spread out with 393 people (23.9%) under the age of 18, 135 people (8.2%) aged 18 to 24, 367 people (22.3%) aged 25 to 44, 531 people (32.2%) aged 45 to 64, and 221 people (13.4%) who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 41.3 years. For every 100 females there were 104.9 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 104.9 males.

There were 1,005 housing units at an average density of 182.4 per square mile (70.4/km²), of which 440 (61.5%) were owner-occupied, and 275 (38.5%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 5.3%; the rental vacancy rate was 15.1%.  977 people (59.3% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 670 people (40.7%) lived in rental housing units.

===2000===
As of the [[census]]<ref name="GR2">{{cite web|url=http://factfinder2.census.gov|publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]]|accessdate=2008-01-31|title=American FactFinder}}</ref> of 2000, there were 1,998 people, 795 households, and 520 families residing in the CDP.  The [[population density]] was 362.5 people per square mile (140.0/km²).  There were 1,048 housing units at an average density of 190.1 per square mile (73.4/km²).  The racial makeup of the CDP was 88.39% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 5.26% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.25% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.55% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 2.70% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 2.85% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 8.51% of the population.

There were 795 households out of which 36.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 46.4% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 12.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 34.5% were non-families. 28.1% of all households were made up of individuals and 10.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.51 and the average family size was 3.10.

In the CDP the population was spread out with 31.4% under the age of 18, 6.1% from 18 to 24, 26.9% from 25 to 44, 24.3% from 45 to 64, and 11.3% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females there were 100.6 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 96.8 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $24,148, and the median income for a family was $30,195. Males had a median income of $29,219 versus $23,646 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the CDP was $13,178.  About 16.7% of families and 22.5% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 30.0% of those under age 18 and 1.9% of those age 65 or over.

==Economy==
The [[San Joaquin and Eastern Railroad]] sold Shay locomotive Lima #2534 to the Red River Lumber Company.<ref>{{cite book| title=The Shay Locomotive Titan of the Timber |author=Koch, Michael |publisher=The World Press |year=1971 |pages=440&442}}</ref>

The [[BNSF Railway]] (BNSF) has a Maintenance of Way station and a siding that is used to store BNSF snow fighting equipment.

The Westwood Community Services District serves 2,000 people.<ref>{{cite news|last=Duhigg|first=Charles|title=16 Water Systems in Lassen County, California|url=http://projects.nytimes.com/toxic-waters/contaminants/ca/lassen/ca1810002-westwood-csd|accessdate=8 March 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=December 16, 2009}}</ref>

==Government==
In the [[California State Legislature|state legislature]], Westwood is in {{Representative|casd|1|fmt=sdistrict}},<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://senate.ca.gov/senators |title=Senators |accessdate=March 10, 2013  |publisher=State of California}}</ref> and {{Representative|caad|1|fmt=adistrict}}.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://assembly.ca.gov/assemblymembers |title=Members Assembly |accessdate=March 2, 2013 |publisher=State of California}}</ref>

Federally, Westwood is in {{Representative|cacd|1|fmt=district}}.<ref>{{Cite GovTrack|CA|1|accessdate=March 2, 2013}}</ref>

== Points of interest ==
Westwood is the site of the [[Walker family]] mansion and statues of Paul Bunyan and Babe the Blue Ox.

The "Bizz" Johnson Trail, ends {{convert|4|mi|km}} north of Westwood, at Mason Station.  Named for [[Harold T. Johnson]], U.S. Congressman from California, the [[rail trail]] follows the {{convert|24.5|mi|km}} [[Fernley and Lassen Railway]] right-of-way.<ref>[http://knowledgecenter.unr.edu/specoll/mss/91-16.html A guide to the records of Jim Bryant, Collection No. 91-16], University of Nevada collections of historical material about Red River Lumber Company and Fernley and Lassen Railroad, June 23, 2008, accessed March 8, 2014</ref>

==Notable people==
<!-- to be included, subject must have own Wikipedia page first!  Alphabetical order, small summary and citations required.  -->

*[[Pat O'Dea]], pioneering, Australian-born American Football kicker for the [[Wisconsin Badgers]], fled an embezzlement charge in [[San Francisco]] and lived in Westwood under the pseudonym "Charles J. Mitchell" between 1919 and 1934.<ref name="The Opening Kickoff 1995">{{cite book | last = Revsine | first = Dave | title = The Opening Kickoff: the Tumultuous Birth of a Football Nation | publisher = Lyons Press | location = Greenwood | year = 2014 | isbn =978-0762791774|ref=Revsine}}</ref>
*[[John H. Tolan]] a [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] from [[California]] died in Westwood on June 30, 1947.<ref>[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=7392955 John H. Tolan], Find a Grave, accessed March 8, 2014</ref>
*[[T. B. Walker]] successful [[United States|American]] [[businessperson]] who acquired [[timber]] in [[Minnesota]] and [[California]] and became an [[collection (museum)|art collector]], founding the [[Minneapolis Public Library]] and the [[Walker Art Center]].  In 1923, he was among the ten wealthiest men in the world.<ref name=Madison>{{cite book|author=Madison, Cathy|title=Walker Art Center|publisher=Scala|year=2005|pages=5–13|isbn=1-85759-377-4}}</ref> He built two [[company town]]s, including Westwood, which one of which his son sold to become part of what is today known as [[Sunkist Growers, Incorporated|Sunkist]].

==See also==
*[[Moonlight Fire]]
*[[Mountain Meadows Reservoir]]

==Additional reading==

*[http://www.flickr.com/photos/foresthistory/sets/72157624682326335/ Gallery of logging photos of Westwood.]

*[http://www.westwoodareachamber.com/index.php Westwood Area Chamber of Commerce]
==Climate==
According to the [[Köppen Climate Classification]] system, Westwood has a [[Mediterranean climate#Warm-summer Mediterranean climate|warm-summer Mediterranean climate]], abbreviated "Csa" on climate maps.<ref>[http://www.weatherbase.com/weather/weather-summary.php3?s=6940&cityname=Westwood%2C+California%2C+United+States+of+America&units= Climate Summary for Westwood, California]</ref>

title: St Lawrence Parish Church, Hunworth
content:
[[File:Hunworth Church 3.JPG|thumb|right|275px]]

'''St Lawrence Parish Church''' is a Grade II* [[listed building]] in the village of [[Hunworth]] in [[Norfolk]], England. The church is dedicated to [[Lawrence of Rome|Saint Lawrence]] who was martyred in 258 AD.

==History==
The exact date of the construction of the church is not known but the style of the aisle-less [[nave]] which is the oldest part of the current building, is early [[Norman architecture|Norman]] and dates it to the 11th century. The church is constructed in [[Flint#As a building material|flint work]] and the external south wall which also dates from the Norman period is typical of early work with this material with whole flints laid in wide courses. The south wall had a double splayed window which is also typical of the early Norman period, it was not rediscovered until a 1960s refurbishment. Further expansion of the church continued with the external north wall being constructed in the early 12th century with more loose coursed flints. The [[Perpendicular Gothic|Perpendicular]] windows in the south wall were added in the 1350s and indicate the modifications in design and construction after the impact of the [[Black Death in England|Black Death]]. A three stage tower was added around 1370 at the west end of the church, this probably replaced an earlier tower.<ref name="Historic England">[http://list.historicengland.org.uk/resultsingle.aspx?uid=1049189&searchtype=mapsearch Historic England] Gives details of architecture and some history.</ref>

The church underwent a substantial reconstruction in the middle part of the  15th century. The three stage tower was raised to its current height with the addition of a belfry with decorative [[battlement]]s, it was also strengthened by two diagonal buttresses and modifications to the tower arch. The belfry originally had three bells but two of these were sold in 1746, the remaining bell was cast by the bell founders William Brend of [[Norwich]]. The south [[transept]] was also added at this time and its fine construction and design indicates it was probably a gift from a wealthy patron of the church, it was used as the [[Lady chapel]] with a [[piscina]] for washing the church vessels. The internal roof of the south transept is the only medieval woodwork left in the church. The south [[porch]] was also added during the 15th century restoration, this disproportionately tall building was typical of the middle 15th century, the lower diagonal buttresses have a flint design of an L with a crown and a griddle on top and refers to the martyrdom of St Lawrence.<ref name="Norfolk coast">[http://norfolkcoast.co.uk/churches/ch_hunworth.htm Norfolk Coast] Gives historical details.</ref>
[[File:Hunworth Church slab.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Memorial to Edmund and Henrietta Britliffe]]
In 1779 the original [[chancel]] was devastated in the great New Year gale of that year, many of the original [[medieval]] features were lost, including [[stained glass]] windows, wall paintings and [[rood screen]]. The chancel was not rebuilt until 1850 when the Reverend [[James Bulwer]] directed the restoration and includes the triple [[Lancet window|lancet]] east window. Bulwer was St Lawrence’s most famous incumbent and became Rector in 1848, he was a well known antiquarian and artist. He amassed a huge collection of historical papers, many of which are now at [[Norwich Castle]] Museum. He was also a gifted artist who was a friend of [[John Sell Cotman]] and a patron of [[Frederick Sandys]]. Several of Bulwer’s watercolours of St Lawrence’s church are stored in Norwich Castle Museum. His modest grave is on the north side of the churchyard. [[Poppyhead (carving)|Poppyhead]] benches were added to the church during the chancel rebuilding of 1850.<ref name="church leaflet">''"Hunworth Church History"'', Hunworth PCC (August 2008), No ISBN (leaflet), Gives comprehensive history.</ref> In 1935 [[Harold Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Rothermere]] spent several hundred pounds on interior fittings and furnishings, including copies of the [[Book of Common Prayer]], the brass altar vase and the eagle [[lectern]].<ref name="Briningham Benefice">[http://www.brininghambenefice.org.uk/c_hunworth.php Briningham Benifice] Details of Viscount Rothermere.</ref>

===Interior===
The medieval [[font]] stands underneath the west tower, there is a small statue of the church’s patron Saint Lawrence in an alcove on the north side while the floor has ceramic tiling. There are two memorial slabs to the Britiffe family who were local [[gentry]] that rose up the social ladder from modest beginnings, they had strong connections with Hunworth for two centuries. Edmund and his wife Rebecca, who built nearby Hunworth Hall and its adjacent barns, lie beneath a memorial slab in the church nave. Edmund’s son, also Edmund, who was a civil servant, and his daughter Henrietta are buried under an ornate marble slab nearest the altar.<ref name="Norfolk churches">[http://www.norfolkchurches.co.uk/hunworth/hunworth.htm www.norfolkchurches] Gives details of interior.</ref>

'''Sergio Machin''' (sometimes also spelt Makin, born 6 July 1952) is a former [[Croat]]ian [[Association football|football]] player.

Born in [[Rijeka]], as a player he was part of [[HNK Rijeka]]'s golden generation which won the [[Yugoslav Cup]] in [[1977–78 Yugoslav Cup|1978]] and [[1978–79 Yugoslav Cup|1979]].  He was an all round player that could play as a defender, midfielder and forward, although he was most comfortable in the midfield.  Although one of Rijeka's most talented players, he never made an appearance for the Yugoslav national team due to biases in favour of players from the "big four" (Red Star Belgrade, Partizan Belgrade, Dinamo Zagreb and Hajduk Split).<ref>Lazzarich, Marinko (2008) (in Croatian). Kantrida bijelih snova. Rijeka: Adamić. ISBN 978-953-219-393-0, pp. 363–4.</ref>  Before finishing his career, he played the second half of the [[1981–82 Yugoslav First League|1981-82]] season with another [[Yugoslav First League]] club, [[NK Zagreb]].<ref>[http://forum.b92.net/topic/29741-ex-yu-fudbalska-statistika-po-godinama/page__st__127 Stats from Yugoslav leagues] at [[B92]]</ref>

Currently, Sergio Machin lives in [[Novigrad, Istria County|Novigrad]], [[Istria]], where he runs a hotel.<ref>[http://www.tvrtke.com/hotel-makin-vl-sergio-makin,PID-8,MF-41011.aspx]</ref>

title: Wikipedia:Miscellany for deletion/User:Vanished user 9j34rnfjemnrjnasj4/AUSSPORT Portal
User:Daynatitus
content:
Dayna Titus was born in New York City and is the daughter of Marcy Kaiser and Richard Rappaport.    Dayna has three children Andrew, Madison and Sage.    She attended and graduated Marlboro High School and went on to attend and graduate from Douglass College (Rutgers University) in New Brunswick, New Jersey, where she majored in English.

Dayna worked in marketing after college, where she began to learn graphic design.  In doing so, she learned that she loved to edit images for marketing brochures.    That followed with an interest in photography, and her career took a new path when, in 2008, Dayna launched her own photography business Dayna Titus Photography (previously known as Artistic Captures).     At that time, she specialized in lifestyle and portraiture for local clients.     Though very successful and having won several awards (including the completion of a 365 project and named winner of a 1,600 entry photo contest thru www.365project.org), she decided in 2013 to focus on a more family-friendly schedule.

Currently, Dayna Titus is partnered with Getty Images to provide them with quality stock images for use worldwide, in print and on the web.    Dayna's images have been seen in magazines in Europe and South Africa, as well as dozens of websites. 

In addition, Dayna spends a fair amount of time serving on the Jewish National Fund's Northern California Board of Directors (www.jnf.org).    She is a Sapphire Society and President's Society member, having traveled to Israel several times to support philanthropic projects.

Dayna Titus and her family reside in Pleasanton, CA.

== Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Mbarak. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Mbarak~enwiki that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. If you think you might own all of the accounts with this name and this message is in error, please visit [[Special:MergeAccount]] to check and attach all of your accounts to prevent them from being renamed. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation

title: Playthings (magazine)
content:
{{Infobox magazine | title = Playthings | logo = | logo_size = | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = Maria N. Weiskott | editor_title = Editor-in-chief | previous_editor = {{hidden|ta1=left|Editors-in-chief| Robert McCready (1903–1945)
Ben McCready (1945–1980)
Frank Reysen Jr. (1980–2000)}} | staff_writer = | photographer = | category = [[Toy industry|Toy]], [[Game industry|Game]], and related [[Entertainment industry|Entertainment industries]] | frequency = monthly | format = | circulation = | publisher = | paid_circulation = | unpaid_circulation = | circulation_year = | total_circulation = | founder = Robert McCready
Henry C. Nathan | founded = 1902 | firstdate = {{Start date|1903|01}} | finaldate = Fall {{End date|2010}} | finalnumber = | company = Sandow Media | country = USA | based = [[New York City]] | language = English | website = [http://web.archive.org/web/20100710081544/http://www.playthings.com/ www.playthings.com] (defunct)
[http://www.giftsanddec.com/channel/160-playthings www.giftsanddec.com/channel/160-playthings] (current) | issn = 0032-1567 | oclc = }} '''''Playthings''''' is an American [[trade magazine]] focusing on the [[Toy industry|toy]] and [[game industry]]. It was founded in 1902 by editor Robert McCready and publisher Henry C. Nathan, and it was published in physical form by Sandow Media on a monthly basis until Fall 2010 when it became an insert section and was merged with ''[[Gifts & Decorative Accessories]]'' magazine. ''Playthings'' is also published online and is supplemented by a weekly email newsletter, '''''Playthings Extra'''''. The magazine has won multiple [[Jesse H. Neal Award]]s, and is generally regarded as the premier trade magazine of the American toy industry. ==Historical timeline== *1902 - ''Playthings'' is founded by editor Robert McCready and publisher Henry C. Nathan (Henry Nathan Co.). *January 1903 - The inaugural issue is published. In his opening statement, [[editor-in-chief]] McCready describes it as "a regular publication, devoted to ... the more than 20,000 [[Concern (business)|concerns]] [in the United States] engaged in the manufacture or sale of [[doll]]s, [[toy]]s, and [[game]]s." The magazine is 20 pages in length and covers more than 70% European and Asian toys (mostly German and Japanese imports). *January 1904 - Subscription rate and distribution increases. Marking the 1-year anniversary, McCready reports that "the [[Trade (occupation)|trade]] has manifested a cordial interest in us, and has given us hearty support." *1905 - The magazine's primary emphasis settles on coverage of merchants' money-saving techniques and the management of store layout and displays. *June 1910 - Robert McCready founds the McCready Publishing Co. which takes over publication of the magazine from the Henry Nathan Co. McCready serves as the president of publication as well as the editor-in-chief and business manager of the magazine. *June 1912 - The magazine now comprises 198 pages including a few two-color advertisements. *1915-1940 - [[The World Wars|Two World Wars]] strongly impact the importing of foreign toys, and the magazine becomes almost entirely devoted to American-made toys. Distribution now includes international subscribers, but pro-American sentiment is high and the magazine highlights American interests and events like the [[American International Toy Fair]]. *April 1930 - The magazine swells to 290 pages. *1945 - Ben McCready, son Robert McCready, is appointed editor-in-chief. *1950s - ''Playthings'' begins to promote the idea of toy purchasing as a year-round practice rather than primarily a [[Christmas]]-related phenomenon. *1960s - Visual mass media in the form of [[television]] introduce children to a range of celebrities and characters that are soon represented as dolls and [[action figure]]s. The magazine begins to cover television-related toys and reaches its maximum size with some issues exceeding 600 pages in length. *1967 - Publication is taken over by Geyer-McAllister Publications. *1970s - ''Playthings'' begins to cover the topic of [[toy safety]]. *1980s - Frank Reysen Jr. becomes the editor-in-chief and the magazine begins to cover [[electronic games]] and toys both before and after [[North American video game crash of 1983|the 1983 crash]] beginning with [[handheld video game]]s and continuing in the late 1980s with [[video game console]]s. *1984 - ''Playthings'' wins a [[Jesse H. Neal Award]] for coverage of the [[counterfeit]] toy market. *1998 - Geyer-McAllister Publications is acquired by [[Reed Business Information]] which resumes publication. *2000 - Maria N. Weiskott is appointed editor-in-chief. *January 2003 - ''Playthings'' celebrates its [[centenary]] issue with the publication of "Toy Stories: 100 Years of Fun." *2005 - The magazine wins a Jesse H. Neal Award for "Best News Coverage" for reporting on the possible breakup of [[Toys "R" Us]]. *2010 - Reed Business Information sells several properties including ''Playthings'' to Sandow Media which publishes the magazine for a few more issues and then merges it with another Sandow Media publication, ''Gifts & Decorative Accessories'' in the fall. ''Playthings'' becomes an insert section in ''Gifts & Decorative Accessories''. *1 October 2010 - Copies of all physical issues of the magazine (between 1903 and 2010) are acquired by the Brian Sutton-Smith Library & Archives of Play at [[The Strong]] in [[Rochester, New York]]. *12 November 2010 - ''Playthings'' becomes the official national media partner of The [[National Toy Hall of Fame]] at The Strong and enters a 3-year special promotional agreement. ==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= Annicelli, Cliff. "Intriguingly Different..." ''Playthings''. 1 August 2007. {{ISSN|0032-1567}}. Retrieved 23 March 2015 via [[HighBeam Research]] [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-167612367.html here] {{subscription required}}. Annicelli, Cliff. "[http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aJqb7SvBZlwM Playthings Magazine Lists the Top Toys STILL AVAILABLE on Toy]." ''[[Bloomberg L.P.]]'' 30 November 2009. Staff. "[http://libraryandarchivesofplay.tumblr.com/post/102896704049/for-more-than-100-years-playthings-magazine-stood For more than 100 years, Playthings magazine stood]." [[Brian Sutton-Smith Archives of Play]]. 17 November 2014. Cutter, William Richard. ''New England Families, Genealogical and Memorial: A Record of the Achievements of Her People in the Making of Commonwealths and the Founding of a Nation''. Vol.4. Lewis Historical Publishing Company. Pg.2014. 1913. Fell, Jason. "[http://www.foliomag.com/2010/sandow-media-buys-eight-magazines-rbi Sandow Media Buys Eight Magazines from RBI]." ''FolioMag.com''. March 2010. Leccese, Donna. "Playthings Tracks History of Growth, Change." ''Playthings''. 1 September 1993. {{ISSN|0032-1567}}. Retrieved 23 March 2015 via [[HighBeam Research]] [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-14530827.html here] {{subscription required}}. Oliver, Larry. "Words on Play: It's an honor ... Playthings recognized for editorial excellence". ''Playthings''. 1 April 2005. {{ISSN|0032-1567}}. Retrieved 23 March 2015 via [[HighBeam Research]] [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-131958125.html here] {{subscription required}}. Scott, Sharon M. "Playthings" in ''Toys and American Culture: An Encyclopedia''. [[ABC-CLIO]]. Pg.245. 2010. ISBN 9780313351112. Snook, Pam. "[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/playthings-magazine-partners-with-strong-museum-72996627.html Playthings Magazine Partners With Strong Museum]". ''[[PR Newswire]]''. 12 November 2010. Trien, Susan. "[http://www.museumofplay.org/content/more-100-years-playthings-magazine More than 100 Years of Playthings Magazine Acquired by the Brian Sutton-Smith Library & Archives of Play at the Strong in Rochester, New York]". [[The Strong]]. 1 October 2010. Weiskott, Maria N. "[http://www.giftsanddec.com/article/388065-playthings-magazine Milestone: Playthings magazine]." ''[[Gifts & Decorative Accessories]]''. Pg.127. 1 January 2003. {{ISSN|0016-9889}}. title: Taken from Me: The Tiffany Rubin Story
content:
{{Infobox film | name = Taken from Me: The Tiffany Rubin Story | image = | caption = | director = [[Gary Harvey (director)|Gary Harvey]] | producer = Harvey Kahn | writer = Michael Bortman | starring = [[Taraji P. Henson]]
[[Terry O'Quinn]]
Drew Davis
David Haydn-Jones
Sean Baek | music = [[James Horner]] | cinematography = Matthias Herndl | editing = Richard Schwadel | distributor = [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime Television]] | released = {{Start date|2011|1|31}} | runtime = | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Taken from Me: The Tiffany Rubin Story''''' is a [[2011 in film|2011]] original [[Lifetime Movie Network|LMN]] movie, starring [[Taraji P. Henson]] and [[Terry O'Quinn]]. The film follows the events surrounding the kidnapping and rescue of the son of Tiffany Rubin, who was kidnapped by his father and taken to [[South Korea]].[http://articles.nydailynews.com/2008-03-27/local/17893424_1_kobe-south-korea-brooklyn-home Queens mom finds her abducted 7-year-old son in South Korea] on ''[[New York Daily News]]'' (March 27, 2008) ==Plot== The film is based on the dramatic true story of Tiffany Rubin's daring 2008 rescue of her six-year-old son, Kobe, after he was abducted by his [[biological father]] and taken from his home in [[Queens, New York]], all the way to [[Seoul, South Korea]]. At the urging of her mother Belzora, Tiffany seeks the counsel of Mark Miller ([[Terry O'Quinn]]) and his charitable organization, the American Association for Lost Children. With Mark's help, Tiffany is able to travel to Korea to execute a high-stakes plan to bring her son home.[http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/taken-from-me-tiffany-rubin/article/tiffany-rubin-interview An Interview with Tiffany Rubin] on ''[[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]]''[http://www.mahalo.com/tiffany-rubin/ Tiffany Rubin] on Mahalo ==Cast== *[[Taraji P. Henson]] as Tiffany *[[Terry O'Quinn]] as Mark *David Haydn-Jones as Chris *[[Crystal Lowe]] as Perry ==Awards== ''Taken from Me: The Tiffany Rubin Story'' received several award nominations and accolades, mostly for [[Taraji P. Henson]]'s performance. Henson received five nominations to various awards, and won three of them. {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- ! Award ! Category ! Recipient ! Result |- | [[Primetime Emmy Awards]] | Outstanding Lead Actress in a Miniseries or Movie | [[Taraji P. Henson]] | {{nom}} |- | [[NAACP Image Award|Image Awards]] | Outstanding Actress in a Television Movie, Miniseries, or Dramatic Special | [[Taraji P. Henson]] | {{won}} |- | [[BET Awards]] | Best Actress | [[Taraji P. Henson]] | {{won}} |- | rowspan="2"|[[Black Reel Awards]] | Outstanding Television or Miniseries Performance: Female | [[Taraji P. Henson]] | {{won}} |- | Outstanding Television or Miniseries Film | Harvey Kahn | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[Directors Guild of Canada]] | Direction - Television Movie/Miniseries | [[Gary Harvey (director)|Gary Harvey]] | {{nom}} |- | Picture Editing - Television Movie/Miniseries | Richard Scwadel | {{nom}} |} ==See Also== [[Parental child abduction]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=1707825|title=Taken from Me: The Tiffany Rubin Story}} * {{Amg movie|533694|Taken from Me: The Tiffany Rubin Story}} * [http://www.yaare.com/tiffany-rubin%E2%80%99s-story-%E2%80%93-how-she-took-son-back-from-s-korea/ Tiffany Rubin’s story - how she took her son back from S. title: User talk:Ianthomp/TWA
content:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{FULLPAGENAME}}}}
{{TWA/Logo/3}} {{clear}}
==Welcome== Hi {{subst:BASEPAGENAME}}! Welcome to our fantastic collaborative project, where editors build articles based upon reliable sources and help each other to make those articles full of great, neutral information. I thought it might be helpful for your trip to have a place where you can ask questions along the way. There's a special place called the Teahouse, where you can ask any question you have about editing and get friendly help from trusted hosts. We'd like to have you as a guest. Drop by for a cup of tea anytime! * [[Wikipedia:Teahouse]] :Great to have you on board! --[[User:WillKomen|WillKomen]] ([[User talk:WillKomen|talk]]) {{subst:currentdate}} Thanks so much for your friendly welcome [[User:WillKomen]]. I can't wait to start editing! Thanks Will, so far so good[[User:Ianthomp|Ianthomp]] ([[User talk:Ianthomp|talk]]) 11:23, 11 December 2014 (UTC) ==Earth?== Hey {{subst:BASEPAGENAME}}, I see that you're from Planet Earth. I'm also from Planet Earth! I have been working on the Wikipedia article about Planet Earth from Planet Earth. Would you like to give me a hand? --[[User:GaiaGirl86|GaiaGirl86]] ([[User talk:GaiaGirl86|talk]]) {{subst:currentdate}} :Hi [[User:GaiaGirl86|GaiaGirl86]]happy to help, although fixing the planet seems a big ask! You will need to be patient[[User:Ianthomp|Ianthomp]] ([[User talk:Ianthomp|talk]]) 11:30, 11 December 2014 (UTC) :''I'd love to help.''[[User:Ianthomp|Ianthomp]] ([[User talk:Ianthomp|talk]]) 11:32, 11 December 2014 (UTC) :::Hey thanks for fixing up those typos {{subst:BASEPAGENAME}}! I'm not too great with spelling so it's awesome to have you filling that gap. We all do what we're best at here, and it seems like you have some skills we can definitely use. I've added some more content to the article if you want to take a look. Cheers! --[[User:GaiaGirl86|GaiaGirl86]] ([[User talk:GaiaGirl86|talk]]) {{subst:currentdate}} ==A riddle== I ponder a riddle for the few with clue, how do we know what on Wikipedia is true? --[[User:SocraTease|SocraTease]] ([[User talk:SocraTease|talk]]) {{subst:currentdate}} ==Reliable sources== Hi {{subst:BASEPAGENAME}}! I put this information on the Earth article talk page. It's some sources I found. Which one should we use? I'm so glad you're still with me on this. We rock! --[[User:GaiaGirl86|GaiaGirl86]] ([[User talk:GaiaGirl86|talk]]) {{subst:CURRENTDATE}} ==Thanks! What now?== Hey {{subst:BASEPAGENAME}}, it's me again. I flew around the world but now I'm back on Wikipedia. Thanks so much for adding the information to the article. What do we do now though? What if someone wants to check the source themselves, how will they know where to go? --[[User:GaiaGirl86|GaiaGirl86]] ([[User talk:GaiaGirl86|talk]]) {{subst:currentdate}} ==The answer to your question is within== Wikipedia has our preferences, and number one is high quality references. Enjoy these intellectual libations, drink your knowledge from inline citations. --[[User:SocraTease|SocraTease]] ([[User talk:SocraTease|talk]]) {{subst:currentdate}} ==Barnstar of Awesome== {| style="background-color: #fdffe7; border: 1px solid #fceb92;" |rowspan="2" style="vertical-align: middle; padding: 5px;" | [[File:TWA badge 2.png|300px|link=]] |style="font-size: x-large; padding: 3px 3px 0 3px; height: 1.5em;" | '''Barnstar of Awesome''' |- |style="vertical-align: middle; padding: 3px;" | You are hereby awarded the Barnstar of Awesome for your amazing work adding published reliable sources, neutral and relevant information, clear formatting and beautiful images to the Wikipedia Adventure article on Earth. Keep up the stellar job you're doing. Yay you! --[[User:GaiaGirl86|GaiaGirl86]] ([[User talk:GaiaGirl86|talk]]) {{subst:currentdate}} |}

title: User:Mrsevelyn/TWA/Earth/2
content:
{{TWA/Logo/3}} {{clear}}
The '''Earth''' is the third planet from the Sun. It is one of the four terrestrial planets in our Solar System. This means most of its mass is solid. The other three are Mercury, Venus, and Mars. The Earth is also called the Blue Planet, "Planet Earth", and "Terra". The Earth is home to millions of species of plants and animals, including humans. Earth is the only planet in the galaxy known to support life. Earth has many places that are suitable for humans to live in, although some areas of the planet can are dangerous or uninhabitable. Science shows that Earth formed around 4.5 billion years ago. The organisms that live on Earth have completely changed its air (atmosphere); this is called a biosphere. 71% of Earth's surface is covered in salt water oceans. Earth is the only place in the Solar System where liquid water is known to exist at present. The other 29% is made of rocky land in the shape of continents and islands. Earth interacts with other objects in the Solar System, particularly the Sun and the Moon. The Earth orbits the Sun roughly once every 365.25 days. One spin is called a 'day' and one orbit around the Sun is called a 'year'. This is why there are 365 days in a year, but a leap day added to the calendar once every 4 years.Gnawledge, O'penn. "Planet Earth in the Balance of History". Science and Nature Journal. SandNjournal.com/Earthinthebalance. March 21, 20. Retrieved April 24th, 2013. == Shape and structure == [[File:The Blue Marble.jpg|thumbnail|wolrd]] Earth is a terrestrial planet. This means it is made up of solid rock unlike a gas giant such as Jupiter. It is the largest out of the four terrestrial planets in mass and diameter. The Earth's shape is an oblate spheroid. This means it is basically a sphere but it bulges around the middle. The [[circumference]] of the Earth is about 40,000 kilometers; the average width of the Earth is about 12,700 kilometers. The highest point on Earth is the peak of Mount Everest at 8,848 meters above sea level. The lowest natural point is the bottom of the Mariana Trench at 10,911 meters below sea level. Because of the bulge at the middle or the equator, the farthest point from the Earth's center is the top of Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador."Origin of the Moon and Earth". Reisch, Maggy. Nature.com: Volume 10:2, p.19-27. http.www.nature.com/102/Reisch/Earth. Retrieved 2009-07-28. Inside, the Earth is similar to the other terrestrial planets. It has an outer, solid rock layer called the crust. Everything that lives on Earth is on top of the crust. Below that is a layer of thick, semi-liquid rock called the mantle. Under that is a thin liquid layer called the outer core and then the solid iron inner core. The thickness of the crust changes. On land the average is between 30–50 kilometers thick. Under the oceans in some places it is only 6 kilometers thick."Tectonic plates. Shifting Sands". Roberts, Paul. Harvard University Press. http.www.harvard.edu/roberts/shifting. Retrieved 2009-07-28. == Tectonic plates == The Earth is the only terrestrial planet with active plate tectonics. Due to plate tectonics the Earth's crust basically floats on the thick liquid rock of the mantle below. The crust is split up into parts called plates. These plates interact as they move about causing earthquakes and creating volcanoes and mountain ranges. The place where plates meet are called plate boundaries. There are three types of plate boundary: constructive, destructive and transform.Toshiro Tanimoto. "Crustal of the Earth". American Geophysical Union. Retrieved 2009-08-02. == Surface == The Earth changes greatly from place to place. Over 70% of the Earth surface is covered by water. The underwater surface has many of the same features as the above sea with volcanoes, mountains and trenches or canyons. The 30% not covered by water is mostly forests, deserts plains, mountains and plateaus. Human civilization has led to increasing urbanisation — the growth of cities. Many things can change the surface of the Earth. Plate tectonics is main cause of change but there are others such as erosion from wind and rain, erosion by the oceans or meteorite impacts. There are three main types of rock that make up the Earth's surface: Igneous rock is made when magma or lava from the mantle reaches the surface and cools. As it gets colder it turns into rock or solidifies. Sedimentary rock is made from sediment, like sand or small bits of other rock, that has been crushed and packed tightly together. Metamorphic rock which is made when either of the other two types are changed by high or low temperatures and pressures."The Crust". Alphonz, Edgar. Oregon State University. http.www.osu.edu/Alphonz/Crust. Retrieved 2009-07-03. == Atmosphere == A planet's atmosphere is a layer of different gases surrounding it. It is kept there by gravity. The Earth's atmosphere is made of about 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen and small amounts of other gases. This mixture is often called air. Further up there is a layer of ozone gas called the Ozone layer. Ozone absorbs ultraviolet radiation from the Sun. Ultraviolet radiation is dangerous to people, so without the Ozone layer life would not be possible. The atmosphere also protects the earth from crashes with meteors and small asteroids. This is because they burn up due to all the friction as they fly through it. It also helps to keep Earth warm. Some gases including carbon dioxide and methane act like a blanket around the Earth, they trap heat under them, keeping the Earth warm."NASA - Earth's atmosphere". NASA Student Guides. http.www.nasa.gov/student/atmosphere. Retrieved 2009-08-06. == Weather, climate, and water cycle == Hot air rises. As it rises it gets colder again and falls. This creates convection currents. When hot air meets cold air different weather effects happen. Convection currents are the cause of almost all weather on Earth. When it gets hot on the surface water evaporates and becomes steam or water vapour. This hot water vapour rises. As it rises it gets colder. When it gets cold enough it turns back into water again. This causes the clouds and rain. It is called the water cycle."What causes weather?". NASA Student Guides. http.www.nasa.gov/student/weather. Retrieved 2009-08-06 == Orbit and rotation == The Earth takes about 24 hours to complete one day and about 365 days to complete a year. Actually, the Earth take 365.24 days to revolve around the sun. After every four years, an extra day is added, and the year has 366 days. This is a leap year. The Earth is, on average, 150 million kilometers away from the Sun, and moving at a speed of 30 kilometers a second or 108,000 miles an hour. The Moon orbits the Earth at an average distance of 250,000 miles. It is tidally locked to Earth, which means it always has the same side facing the Earth. It takes roughly one month to complete one orbit. The Earth is part of the Solar System and orbits the sun along with thousands of small objects and eight planets. The Sun, and therefore the Solar System, are currently traveling through the Orion Arm of the Milky Way Galaxy and will be for approximately the next 10,000 years."Earth's in the Milky Way". NASA Student Guides. http.www.nasa.gov/student/milkyway. Retrieved 2009-08-06. == References == {{reflist}}

title: Category talk:Thermophiles
User talk:58.97.197.89
content: ==Welcome!== [[Image:Broom icon.svg|150px|right]] Hello, and [[Wikipedia:Introduction|welcome]] to Wikipedia! Thank you for [[Special:Contributions/58.97.197.89|your contributions]], such as the one you made on [[:Nawaz Sharif‎]]. I greatly appreciate your efforts to fight [[Wikipedia:Vandalism|vandalism]] and make constructive edits on Wikipedia. I hope you like the place and decide to stay. Here are some pages you might like to see: * [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]] * [[Wikipedia:How to edit a page|How to edit a page]] * [[Help:Contents|Help pages]] * [[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Tutorial]] * [[Wikipedia:How to write a great article|How to write a great article]] * [[Wikipedia:Your first article|How to create your first article]] (using the [[Wikipedia:Article wizard|Article Wizard]] if you wish) * [[Wikipedia:Simplified Manual of Style|Simplified Manual of Style]] * [[Wikipedia:Recent changes patrol|Recent changes patrol]] * [[Wikipedia:Cleaning up vandalism/Tools|Anti-vandalism tools]] You are welcome to continue editing without [[Special:Userlogin|logging in]], but many editors recommend that you '''[{{fullurl:Special:Userlogin|type=signup}} create an account]'''. Doing so is free, requires no personal information, and provides several benefits such as the ability to create articles. For a full outline and explanation of the benefits that come with creating an account, please see [[Wikipedia:Why create an account?|this page]]. If you edit without a username, your [[IP address]] (58.97.197.89) is used to identify you instead. In any case, I hope you enjoy editing here and being a [[Wikipedia:Wikipedians|Wikipedian]]! Please [[Wikipedia:Signatures|sign your comments]] on talk pages using four tildes (~~~~); this will automatically produce your IP address (or username if you're logged in) and the date. If you need help, check out [[Wikipedia:Questions]], ask me on [[User talk:Bonadea|my talk page]], or ask your question and then place {{[[:Category:Wikipedians looking for help|helpme]]}} before the question on this page. Again, welcome! ''[[User:Bonadea|bonadea]]'' [[Special:Contributions/Bonadea|contributions]] [[User talk:Bonadea|talk]] 16:47, 26 May 2013 (UTC)

title: User talk:V0id~enwiki
content:
== Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called V0id. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name V0id~enwiki that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. If you think you might own all of the accounts with this name and this message is in error, please visit [[Special:MergeAccount]] to check and attach all of your accounts to prevent them from being renamed. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation
03:29, 20 March 2015 (UTC) == Renamed ==

To do this, add {{tl|hangon}} on the top of the page (just below the existing speedy deletion or "db" tag) and leave a note on the page's talk page explaining your position. Please do not remove the speedy deletion tag yourself. If the page you created was a test, please use the [[Wikipedia:Sandbox|sandbox]] for any other experiments you would like to do. Feel free to leave a message on my talk page if you have any questions about this. Please use the {{[[Template:hangon|hangon]]}} template on the page instead if you disagree with the deletion. {{#if:|{{{2}}}|Thank you.}} [[User:HalfShadow|'''Half''']][[User talk:HalfShadow|'''Shadow''']] 03:49, 18 September 2008 (UTC) [[Image:Nuvola apps important.svg|25px]] Please stop removing [[Wikipedia:Speedy deletions|speedy deletion]] notices from pages that you have created yourself{{#if:Tiddlewinks|, as you did with [[:Tiddlewinks]]}}. If you continue, you will be [[Wikipedia:Blocking policy|blocked]] from editing Wikipedia. {{#if:|{{{2}}}|}} [[User:HalfShadow|'''Half''']][[User talk:HalfShadow|'''Shadow''']] 03:54, 18 September 2008 (UTC) ==Speedy deletion of [[:RaptorJesus]]== [[Image:Ambox warning_pn.svg|48px|left]] Please refrain from introducing inappropriate pages such as [[:RaptorJesus]], to Wikipedia. Doing so is not in accordance with our [[Wikipedia:List of policies|policies]]. If you would like to experiment, please use the [[Wikipedia:Sandbox|sandbox]]. If you think that this notice was placed here in error, you may contest the deletion by adding {{tl|hangon}} to '''the top of [[:RaptorJesus|the page that has been nominated for deletion]]''' (just below the existing speedy deletion or "db" tag), coupled with adding a note on '''[[ Talk:RaptorJesus|the talk page]]''' explaining your position, but be aware that once tagged for ''speedy'' deletion, if the article meets the criterion it may be deleted without delay. Please do not remove the speedy deletion tag yourself, but don't hesitate to add information to the article that would would render it more in conformance with Wikipedia's policies and guidelines. Lastly, please note that if the article does get deleted, you can contact [[:Category:Wikipedia administrators who will provide copies of deleted articles|one of these admins]] to request that a copy be emailed to you.
